name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament interrupted on 2 March 2017.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before starting the session I would like to express my condolences and express my closeness to the families of the victims of the people of Guatemala, for the tragedy caused by a fire that broke out last Wednesday in a shelter for orphaned minors victims of violence in San José Pinula. We await the result of the investigation to find out the causes of this event and any responsibilities. What is certain is that these children and adolescents had to be better protected. As you know, last week we celebrated Women's Day. I insisted that this celebration is not just a rhetorical occasion and as long as women continue to be victims of violence, discrimination, forced marriages, exclusion from the world of work, politics or positions of responsibility, we will have to fight every day of the year to affirm respect for their fundamental rights. At the extraordinary meeting of the FEMM commission, I stressed that it is not possible to respond to the great challenges of the world - terrorism, radicalization, poverty and unemployment - without true gender equality. I met Lamiya Aji Bashar and Hauwa Ibrahim, two women winners of our Sakharov prize; I reaffirmed our commitment to support their action but also their courage and their history must make us responsible so that the Union remains a beacon of human rights in the world. This is why we ask for a collective effort by the Member States and by the European institutions themselves for the ratification and application of the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. I am proud to be the President of an institution that makes its voice heard loud and clear on women's rights every day. Yet, right here, in the European Parliament, a few days ago, we witnessed an extremely serious episode: a parliamentarian attacked in a manner gender equality is unacceptable.He has offended all women by violating our founding values and more so while presiding over a woman as part of a discussion on pay differences between women and men.As far as I am concerned, I do not intend to tolerate such behavior (Applause), even more serious as it is expressed by those who should represent the European peoples with dignity.As President of this Parliament, I want to apologize to all my colleagues, to all the women who work in this institution, to the guests and to all the women, for these extremely offensive statements.As soon as the process of the investigation that I have initiated is completed, I will announce the sanction which will be appropriate to the gravity of the statements made in this chamber.(Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules, was distributed at the meeting of 9 March 2017.Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal to amend the final draft agenda.Thursday: The discussion on "Sudan: the cases of Hassan Abduraheem and Abdulmonen Abdumawla is replaced by the discussion on" Zimbabwe, the case of Pastor Evan Mawarire ". The agenda is changed as follows. Monday: I announce that I have received arequest by the Europe of Nations and Freedoms Group to add a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Wikileaks revelations on the hacking tools used by the CIA; consequently thesession would be extended until midnight.

name: Marcus Pretzell
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! WikiLeaks has published initial documents on the CIA's activities in hacking smartphones, even televisions and other things, including cars, and has announced that it will publish more. Viruses, Trojans - under certain circumstances even cars can be controlled remotely. The technology covers its tracks on its own, and there is no guarantee that CIA officials cannot use it for their own purposes without the CIA's knowledge. From this point of view of the blurring of traces and the creation of false fingerprints - including conceivable Russian fingerprints - the attacks on the elections in France 2012 may also have to be viewed in a different light. The CIA hackers operate from the US consulate in Frankfurt as a base in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. The German federal government has so far refused to comment publicly. But we need a public debate, and I believe that this is not a debate that only needs to be held in Germany. I believe that this is a debate that affects all European countries and we should have that debate here in this Parliament today.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: - Mr President!I want us to put the vote on the Arms Directive on the agenda.As the new Weapons Directive has not been preceded by an impact assessment, the proposal is not ready to be voted on.That is why I am asking for the Arms Directive to be deleted from the agenda and sent back to the Commission for an impact assessment.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: - Mister President!Cheers even before I speak, thank you very much!On the agenda on Thursday afternoon is the big question from the EFDD Group, and I just ask that the title be added to the agenda and not just the reference to the document.It is important that we know what we are talking about on Thursday afternoon: the cooperation between the smugglers and non-governmental organizations involved in search and rescue operations in the Mediterranean.This is an important part of towing in the Mediterranean.So I just ask that the title of the question be put on the agenda, as is customary - now and then in the future.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mrs von Storch: The title decision is taken by the Conference of Group Leaders and the chairman of your group has attended all the meetings.So, you know what the topic is.Mr Winberg: There are deadlines to request changes and his request is out of time.Tuesday: The European United Left / Nordic Green Left group called for a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the continuing demolition of Palestinian-owned homes and structures to be added as a thirditem on the agenda in the afternoon, following the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Union's priorities for the sessions of the UN Human Rights Council in 2017The discussion will end with a resolution.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Israel's criminal policy of demolition against the Palestinian people continues. Yesterday was the last day given by the Israeli authorities to the Bedouin community to demolish their houses in the village of Khan al-Ahmar on the west coast of Palestine. This Bedouin community is in immediate danger. It consists of 140 inhabitants, most of whom are children. In fact, a kindergarten was built in the settlement with funding from the European Union. The European Parliament delegation for relations with Palestine had recently visited this village and due to our presence there the Israeli authorities have postponed the demolition, which was scheduled to take place in February. I must say that according to the UN data, in 2016 the most demolition was done by Israel, and in 2017 the Israeli authorities have already demolished 172 Palestinian structures in the C region and in East Jerusalem. It is Israel's policy to demolish the settlements, expand the illegal Israeli settlements and divide the West Bank in two. It is time for the European Union to act immediately, to ensure that the illegal demolition and illegal expansion of Israeli settlements is stopped. The European Parliament must send the message: It opposes these illegal demolitions, opposes the illegal expansion of Israeli settlements and supports the two-state solution, which is the only option today for lasting peace in the wider Middle East.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, we are against this proposal, because in the Kahn al-Ahmar community, which is in zone C, what is illegal there is precisely the buildings.I remind you that in zone C, it is the Israelis who have control of all the territory and activities.The Palestinians did not ask for the agreement to build;they are using all legal avenues.The Israelis have also mentioned that there will be no demolition until all legal channels have been exhausted.There is therefore no question of introducing this confusion that my colleague wants to introduce.He was talking about the impending demolition in February.We are - I draw his attention - in March.So I repeat that the Israelis have made it clear that all legal avenues will be accepted for the Palestinians.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: - I would like to talk a little bit about Turkey, about the statements of Mr Erdogan, who profiles himself strongly against the European Union.We have seen the riots in the Netherlands, we have heard the statements of Mr. Erdogan who calls the Dutch fascists, whom they call Nazis.This is not possible.We cannot tolerate this as the European Parliament.I sincerely think we should add this to this week's agenda.I know this is on the agenda for the April session, but we have the political news.You can rightly hide behind the procedures, behind the rules and say that this has not been done on time.That's right, this wasn't put on in time: I'm saying this now.But we can also do something else.We also cannot hide behind the rules and debate about what is politically topical - as real politicians, as a real parliament - and therefore also enter the debate about Turkey this week.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mrs Loones, the rules must be respected.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I know that your procedure is very democratic and I very much appreciate you for giving your words to colleagues, but I would like to recall Rule 184a of the Rules of Procedure.If a colleague wants to make these statements, he should have asked for a one-minute speech, as we all ask of others if we want to make similar statements.Next time, please refer him to the one-minute speeches, in accordance with Rule 184a of the Rules of Procedure, so that my colleague can make this remark there in a one-minute speech.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: -  Mister President! Something else on the agenda: I would like to briefly point out that the alternative motion for a resolution tabled by Mr Dantin in connection with the own-initiative report on minimum standards for farm rabbits exceeded the allowed number of words by the deadline last Thursday, which is contrary to Rule 170 (3) of the Violates the Rules of Procedure of this House. The President decides on the admissibility of such amendments. Before the vote, the President shall obtain the approval of Parliament to vote on such motions ”. Mr President, in this context I ask you whether you consider the EPP's alternative motion for a resolution admissible or whether you are putting it to the vote here, as is the rule in this House.

name: Presidente. –
text: The proposal from the Group of the European People's Party was longer than allowed and, as you know, the alternative proposal must be shorter than the original proposal.Our services, as always, have informed the EPP Group and the text has been reduced.Therefore, since it is only a technical problem linked to the length of the text and not of contents or violation of the rules, I consider this document admissible.Again, it was just a technical matter.The services have already solved the problem.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Stefan Eck, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on mercury repealing Regulation (EC) no.1102/2008 (COM (2016) 0039 - C8-0021 / 2016 - 2016/0023 (COD)) (A8-0313 / 2016)

name: Stefan Eck
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Mercury is acutely toxic and is one of the ten most harmful naturally occurring substances on this planet. Fetuses, newborns and children belong to the particularly endangered group, as the brain and nervous system are very sensitive to mercury during the growth phase. Even small amounts of ingested mercury can cause serious damage to health. In the 1950s, thousands of people and many animals in the Japanese coastal city of Minamata were diagnosed with massive and irreparable damage to the central nervous system. The media talked about Minamata disease. The cause of these diseases was a high degree of mercury poisoning, caused by the discharge of contaminated sewage from a local chemical factory into the sea. According to current estimates, around ten thousand people were seriously harmed and around three thousand died as a result of the poisoning. Given the dangers to human health and the environment, an in-depth approach would have been necessary to meet our responsibilities rather than just making cosmetic corrections. Above all, I saw my task as rapporteur in representing the approach of the Minamata Convention as best as possible and in getting an ambitious proposal off the ground. This approach received broad support from the Environment Committee. That made me very happy and showed that the majority of the committee understood its task. Unfortunately, the compromise that was reached after the second trialogue lacks the ambitious positions that the draft report contained after the vote in the Environment Committee. I would have liked to have gone into a third round of negotiations to defend the parliamentary position. I very much regret that during the negotiations I addressed the crucial questions did not receive the necessary backing from the majority of shadow rapporteurs.In some areas, the report bears the signature of primarily German corporate interests.Nonetheless, I decided to endorse this report in order to pave the way for the ratification of the Minamata Agreement by the EU.Even if I had hoped for a more ambitious text, once the report has been adopted, we can hope for a reduction in the use of mercury, at least in the field of dentistry.After phasing out its use in the chlor-alkali industry this year, the greatest need for mercury in Europe is 75 tonnes per year for amalgam fillings.It is now up to the member states to implement this EU legislation into national law as soon as possible.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, mercury is a pollutant of global concern that enters the food chain where it accumulates, mainly in fish. The EU’s mercury policy is the most advanced worldwide, but 40-80% of the mercury deposited in the EU comes from other parts of the globe. That is why we called for global action and took on a leading role in the negotiations of the Minamata Convention on Mercury. The Convention, which was signed at the end of 2013, is to a great extent inspired by EU legislation, so it requires only limited changes to the EU acquis. Consequently, the new mercury regulation aims primarily at fine-tuning EU law so as to ensure full compliance with all provisions of the Minamata Convention and enable its ratification by the EU and the Member States. We expect that ratification by the EU and those Member States that have completed their required national procedures will take place before the end of June. This should trigger the entry into force of the Convention, taking us a major step closer to a safer, healthier mercury-free society. As top mercury-polluters take action to implement the Convention, we expect a dramatic drop of mercury emissions to air and water worldwide, leading to reduced exposure to mercury within the EU. The entry into force of the Minamata Convention will help level the playing field, as all major economies will apply requirements similar to those already applying in the EU on products, industrial processes and waste management. In turn, this will support the EU’s innovative eco-industry, which will be able to make the most of their technological lead in export markets. Furthermore, this regulation is a golden opportunity to complement our already advanced EU acquis with new measures going beyond the minimum of the Convention. The Commission is very happy that Parliament fully supported our proposal to put an end to new uses of mercury in products and industrial processes. This flagship measure demonstrates the EU’s continued global leadership in this policy area. The new regulation will also ensure that all known industrial processes using mercury convert to mercury-free alternatives and that mercury waste is safely start out of reach, thereby avoiding its improper use and release into the environment. Finally, the regulation sets out a clear road map for reducing the use of dental amalgam and assessing the feasibility of phasing out its use. I also draw your attention to two statements by the Commission that will be appended to the Minutes. The first one signals our continued engagement at international level, which will aim at further narrowing the remaining gaps between the level of protection guaranteed by the Minamata Convention and the stricter requirements that prevail in the EU. Our second statement concerns the so-called ‘no opinion clause’ in comitology. The new mercury regulation is undoubtedly a major step forward in the EU acquis. I therefore call upon all of you to express your support for this very good outcome of the informal trilogue process. Commission statement on international cooperation on mercury The Minamata convention and the new Mercury Regulation are major contributions to protecting citizens from mercury pollution globally and in the EU. International cooperation should be sustained to ensure successful implementation of the Convention by all Parties and further strengthen its provisions. The European Commission is therefore committed to supporting continued cooperation, in accordance with the Convention and subject to applicable EU policies, rules and procedures, inter alia undertaking work in the following areas: Narrowing the gap between EU law and the provisions of the Convention through the review clause of the list of prohibited mercury-added products; In the context of the provisions of the Convention on financing, capacity building and technology transfer, activities such as improving traceability of mercury trade and use, promoting certification of mercury-free artisanal and  small-scale gold mining and mercury-free labels for gold, and increasing the capacity of developing countries including in the area of mercury waste management. Commission statement on comitology The Commission underlines that it is contrary to the letter and to the spirit of Regulation 182/2011 (OJ L 55 of 28.2.2011, p. 13) to invoke Article 5 § 4, subparagraph 2, point b) in a systematic manner. Recourse to this provision must respond to a specific need to depart from the rule of principle which is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered. Given that it is an exception to the general rule established by Article 5 § 4 recourse to subparagraph 2, point b), cannot be simply seen as a "discretionary power" of the Legislator, but must be interpreted in a restrictive manner and thus must be justified.

name: Michel Dantin
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to thank my colleagues in Parliament, the Commission and the Council with whom I have worked closely to improve the protection of European citizens against the harmful effects of mercury. As rapporteur for the PPE Group, I welcome the results of these negotiations. The text that is finally submitted to us seems more realistic than the previous versions. This new text is ambitious to say the least. It puts our Europe at the forefront of the fight against heavy metal pollution on the international stage, but it also leaves our companies and our researchers the time necessary to develop viable alternatives. Among the main elements of the reform, I note that the export of mercury is now prohibited and that the use of recycled mercury is encouraged. With regard to dental amalgams, only encapsulated forms are authorized, guaranteeing both the health of the patient and the health of the practitioners. Dentists should also equip themselves with amalgam separators to avoid any release into the environment. For populations at risk, children, pregnant women, the use of amalgams is prohibited, unless medical advice to the contrary. Lastly, the agreement provides for reducing mercury levels in products and processes. Regarding the management of mercury-containing waste, I fought with my colleagues in the EPP to obtain the safest storage, that is to say after the stabilization of the waste. In the face of heavy metal pollution, the "Mercury" regulation before us today is an example of an efficient Europe that protects. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, a Europe that protects. I hope that the Union will defend its ambitious goals with force at the conference of the International Minamata Convention, next September in Geneva.

name: Massimo Paolucci
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, mercury poses very serious risks to human health and to the environment, risks that have been guilty underestimated for too many years. For this reason it is necessary to regulate its uses and movements and to decide in perspective how to treat it when it becomes waste with the aim, where possible, of reducing or eliminating its use in a reasonable amount of time. With this logic we moved in the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, which concluded last December with a broad consensus, which then received unanimity in the Environment Committee. Tomorrow we hope that the text can be definitively approved, without further amendments by the House. This will make it possible for the Union to ratify the Minamata Convention on mercury and take part in its first conference of the parties scheduled for the end of September in Geneva. But neither today's debate nor tomorrow's vote are formal at all: the text we bring to plenary, which is the result of the contribution of almost all the political groups, marks some major changes compared to the Commission's initial proposal. I want to name just a few: dental amalgam in the first place. Currently, this is the first form of mercury use in Europe and presents several risks to citizens' health and the environment. For this reason, we would have liked its use to be completely outdated within a few years. We did not succeed, also due to the resistance of the Council. However, compared to the Commission's initial proposal, we have achieved: first, a ban on the use of amalgam for vulnerable populations (pregnant women, breastfeeding women, children under 15, all baby teeth) from 1 January 2019; second, the drawing up of national plans for the gradual reduction of the use of amalgam; third, a report of the Commission by June 2020 on the feasibility of the total elimination of the use of amalgam; fourth, we have achieved that dental facilities that use dental amalgam are equipped with amalgam separators, so as to avoid their discharge into municipal wastewater. We have been able to introduce other important changes with respect to the initial text on mercury-contaminated sites, which will finally be identified and made public, with the hope that the States can soon accept a legislative initiative from the Union. Furthermore, we will finally be able to apply the mercury content limits defined for the internal market to the export of batteries and non-electronic measuring devices, thereby overcoming incomprehensible double standards between what we sell within the Union and what we export. Unfortunately, we have not obtained a similar ambition on the export of lamps: but in any case on many of them, from 2018, mercury limits lower or equal to those defined according to the Minamata Convention will apply. Thanks to the commitment of the European Parliament, several production processes that still use mercury will have an expiration date and companies will be induced to find alternatives that are more sustainable from an environmental point of view. Finally, the waste. Here too the contribution was important, they will be solidified and placed in safe places.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am pleased to speak tonight in favour of the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Slovak Presidency in December. This deal will help to close the gap between international efforts under the UN Minamata Convention and efforts at the EU level. The updated regulation will also allow the EU to give consent to ratification of the Minamata Convention, which was signed in 2013. This was not an easy negotiation, but on balance the compromise reached is a good outcome. Although mercury use has declined significantly in recent years, releases into the air, water and land can still be a threat. This agreement will help improve protection of human health and the environment from exposure to mercury. There are updated provisions regarding the scope of exports and imports and the storage of mercury waste. Mercury use will also be banned in artisanal and small—scale gold mining, whilst the compromise reached on the phasing-out of mercury in dental usage is welcome. There is a ban on the use of amalgam for children under 15 and pregnant and breastfeeding women from 2018. Member States will have to adopt national action plans on the phase-down of mercury in dentistry and the Commission will study the feasibility of a complete phase-out in the long term, preferably by 2030. This gradual approach is important. I am a firm proponent of decision-making on the basis of scientific evidence. Dental amalgam is safe, effective and durable. The WHO supports a phase-down, recognising the need for further research and improved prevention. I therefore ask Members to join with me and vote against amendments tabled by the rapporteur and the EFDD Group. This attempt to undermine a carefully-negotiated trilogue agreement must be defeated.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - (FI) Mr President, the mercury regulation now being negotiated will significantly reduce mercury emissions and use in Europe. A particularly important achievement is the ban on the use of dental amalgam sites for children, pregnant women and nursing mothers. At present, the majority of the mercury imported into Europe is used to make dental amalgam. In the coming years, the Commission will be required to assess the possibility of a total ban on amalgam use. Some Member States are not prepared to give up the use of amalgam, but with this decision we are sending a clear message to the citizens of their will to reduce their use and move to cost-effective, mercury-free dental places. A total ban on amalgam would have very positive environmental and health effects in Europe and in those non-European countries where mercury is mined. With the Mercury Regulation, EU legislation meets and must meet the criteria of the UN Minamata Agreement. However, as new technologies develop, we must be prepared to make our legislation even stricter on the use of this mercury. Mercury is one of the ten most toxic substances according to the World Health Organization, and exposure to mercury causes diseases of the nervous system and internal organs, among other things. In addition to the negative effects on humans, mercury also affects ecosystems and animals, especially in catchments and coastal waters. Among other things, alarmingly high levels of mercury have been measured in the coastal waters of the Baltic Sea. There is a great need for the adoption and entry into force of this regulation. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Eck, and the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation and their persistent defense of Parliament's ambitious position. I think the outcome of the negotiations could have been even more ambitious. However, I recommend that colleagues vote in favor of this compromise. We cannot delay this adoption of an important act.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, mercury is considered to be one of the worst pollutants in nature. It is particularly harmful in aquatic ecosystems, where it is converted to methylmercury and enriched in food chains. With exposure through the environment and the food chain, we have already found that mercury can cause developmental disorders and severe symptoms, even death, in fetuses, including in adults, as the case of Minamata in Japan unfortunately showed. An important objective of the proposal is to protect human health and the environment from mercury emissions to air, water and soil. The regulation covers the entire life cycle of mercury from extraction to mercury waste treatment and also covers the use of mercury comprehensively. Thank you to all the actors for that. This regulation, as well as the Minamata Mercury Agreement on the use of mercury, is particularly important for the Arctic countries, as mercury is a long-range and polar toxic substance. It should be noted that mercury is also released into the environment as a result of the use of fossil fuels, especially coal. I hope that the Member States will ratify this agreement, and I thank Stefan Eck and the shadow rapporteurs in particular for their particularly meritorious work.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for good negotiations – tough negotiations – on this file. Indeed, if you can look on where we come from, the Commission’s proposal was modest – it was a bit of an implementation of the Minamata Convention – and I think the Parliament really strengthened this proposal. Most important is, of course, if you look at how we treat dental amalgam – it has been stated before – we want a direct phase-out for vulnerable groups. It is a national action plan to be drafted by the Member States, and the Commission will come up by 2020 with a proposal for phase-out by 2030. These are good results. Yes, the Parliament would have preferred to go further, absolutely. But we know that in the Council, only one Member State supported that, and that was Sweden; we had 27 Member States not on that position. If you then look – it is Europe – how we got to the compromise, this is a compromise we can support, and we will therefore vote in favour of this deal.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let's start with the scientific data. Mercury exposure negatively impacts the nervous system, digestive system, respiratory system, kidneys, skin and eyes. Mercury has also been recognized as being responsible for Alzheimer's, multiple sclerosis and brain damage in general. We also know that, when dispersed in the environment, it can transform itself into a more complex and harmful compound, methylmercury, which also has the ability to overcome the placental barrier, inhibiting the mental development of children before their birth. Furthermore, the World Health Organization has made it clear that its toxicity is without a threshold, so even very small doses can cause serious damage to health. But despite this, the worldwide use of mercury remains high - around 3 600 tons per year - and the pollution it is responsible for knows no borders. We support the report by my colleague Eck, which responds to these health needs of citizens, and we have also proposed a two-line amendment, with which we can avoid spilling into our seas 75 tons of mercury from derivatives from dental fillings which, still today, unfortunately, they are used in some countries of the European Union.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, after the Minamata disaster which affected Japan for several decades, it was time to take into account the harmful effects of this highly toxic substance, mercury, on health and on our environment . Unfortunately, on a subject of such gravity, where the urgency of action is real, the European Commission does not miss the opportunity to strengthen its prerogatives, once again, while international action would be more effective and especially more legitimate. I welcome, of course, the provisions relating to the scheduled end of dental amalgam containing mercury, in particular to further protect children and pregnant women. At the same time, the text is reasonable and pragmatic in that it continues to allow amalgamations in encapsulated version, when strictly necessary. As regards the transport of mercury and the management of mercury waste, traceability is certainly essential but, here again, it should be carried out primarily at the international level. I find reasonable the idea that third countries manage their mercury waste themselves and entirely within ten years, as provided for in the text. They are thus empowered and will not rely on European countries to do it for them. We can welcome the fact that the text further strengthens transparency, by allowing citizens access to the European pollutant release and transfer register, extended, for the occasion, to the flow of mercury waste. Finally, the text encourages the parties to the Minamata Convention to create a tool for global monitoring of the use and transport of mercury, which appears to be the best framework for action, in terms of efficiency, on an issue. environment of this importance.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: - Mister President! Thank you to everyone who took part in arriving at this result, especially the EPP shadow rapporteur, Mr Dantin. Mercury is poisonous and we need to reduce it. That is why the EPP Group will of course vote for the compromise tomorrow. I believe, however, that compromises can be made, as we did at the end of this report. Because when it comes to how you are exposed to mercury, exposure is very important. So it depends very much on whether it is gaseous or in another form, a bound form. That's why we were happy that in the end you weighed up a few points, for example in the industrial processes, where you have a very closed process, but on the other hand many jobs would have been endangered if we had left this process too quickly. There are also very many different views on amalgam. I think it has to be a goal - that's why I welcome the compromise - that we get rid of amalgam if possible. Because there are question marks, and if there are question marks, it is better if we have alternatives. But the experts are still arguing about how available these alternatives are and how quickly we can replace them completely. That is why it is right to start immediately with the sensitive groups and specify the direction of attack, but not now - especially not without an impact assessment - to adopt the complete ban immediately. Finally, one more sentence on a subject that has not played a role in this report, but which does play a role in the public discussion about mercury. It's about the mercury in energy-saving lamps. We have regulated that with RoHS. There are very, very strict limits. There isn't much left. Compared to the thermometers we used to have, that's more than a hundred times less. But we mustn't forget that a lot of mercury is produced when coal is burned, and the Commission has calculated that the use of energy-saving lamps - if they are still necessary, if you don't have newer technologies - still makes sense because they can save coal-fired power stations.And in the end this is not only good for the environment in general, but also especially for mercury.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate my colleagues on the agreement reached on the proposal for a regulation on mercury. I am very pleased to note that the European Parliament has again succeeded in substantially improving the European Commission's original proposal. The new rules aim to strengthen protection against pollution by this highly toxic substance, and the agreed changes will ensure that EU legislation is in line with the international rules set out in the Minamata Convention. This will make it possible to ratify the text of the Convention quickly by the EU, paving the way for its early entry into force. Global cooperation is key and essential: pollution by this substance knows no borders and while, since the entry into force of Regulation (EC) No 1102/2008, annual demand for mercury in the EU has fallen to around 400 tonnes, global consumption is still high at 3,600 tonnes per year. . At the same time, mercury poses a serious threat to human health, precisely due to the presence of its compound methylmercury in fish and seafood. And from that point of view, it is alarming that more than 13% of fish samples from around the world would probably not be recommended for commercial sale by either the WHO or the European Commission. It is clear that without international cooperation, this problem simply cannot be solved. It is positive that the proposal ultimately takes a rational approach to the gradual reduction of amalgam, starting with particularly vulnerable groups and with the aim of a total ban. I am also glad that the ENVI Committee did not support some problematic proposals. I consider the agreement reached to be highly successful, balanced and I unequivocally support it and recommend its adoption.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! It is indisputable that mercury is a threat to human life and health as well as to the environment. Therefore, I fully support the updating of EU law, which is in line with the activities of the international community and is aimed at limiting the use and release of mercury into the environment, as underlined by the UN program and the Minamata Convention. I also support the position on the gradual phasing out of dental amalgam - which contains mercury after all. However, it must be remembered that measures taken to limit the use of mercury and mercury products must be based on common sense. These must be deliberate decisions, not just emotional. A complete, immediate ban on the use of dental amalgam would not be a perfect solution, neither economically nor technically. Hence, I believe that our approach is balanced and will probably fit in with the general medical principle primum non nocere - first, do no harm. ECR supports this project.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Many thanks also to the rapporteur for the report. Mercury is highly toxic - we've heard that on various occasions. I actually knew from an early age how toxic it is because my mother always made it clear to us that, for God's sake, we shouldn't drop the thermometer that used to measure fever, where you can see the liquid mercury, because which otherwise actually releases harmful substances and would also harm us. Because we're talking about children - Peter Liese mentioned energy-saving lamps: I thought it was very bad at the time that lightbulbs were banned and energy-saving lamps came because they contain mercury. We have two cases in Germany where a child, because such an energy-saving lamp broke, burned itself to the fumes and was marked by it for life. Of course, that shouldn't happen. Fortunately, that only happened twice, but still. That said, mercury is highly toxic. It has also been said to be found everywhere in the environment, in fish, in seafood. Of course that shouldn't be. We have it in the ground and we have to try to reduce that. I therefore agree, like everyone else, that amalgam is to be banned now, especially for small children with their milk teeth and for pregnant women and nursing mothers. This is really necessary because otherwise poisoning can happen, especially in children, in an indirect or direct way. I also think it's good that people are looking into whether amalgam, which contains mercury, shouldn't be generally banned sooner or later. The Commission has been asked to make a proposal here. That is also perfectly correct. I would like to address one more aspect that did not play such a major role in the debate or has not yet been addressed at all: There are some areas in medicine where mercury is irreplaceable, but where it has so far been used correctly, even in very small doses.That is with homeopathy and with anthroposophic medicine.I think it is very good - I have also tabled relevant amendments here - that you can still do that, because otherwise there would be no more options for certain therapies.Mind you: Paracelsus said that the dose makes the poison.It is so minimal there that it helps people, but does not damage the environment significantly.Overall, we should definitely vote in favor of this regulation, because it is perfectly right and tries to protect people more.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, mercury is one of the biggest pollutants in the world with significant and lasting impacts on human health and the environment. According to WHO, there are no safe limits with regard to exposure to this heavy metal. About two to three thousand tons are released annually into the atmosphere due to various human activities. Once in the environment, mercury accumulates along food chains through a process of bioaccumulation. Eating foods contaminated with methylmercury - the most toxic organic chemical form - is an important source of contamination. The restrictions on the use of mercury, import, export, storage and production of products and processes are therefore entirely justified, and we even think that it would have been possible to go further in this area, as demonstrated by the work done by the rapporteur and the initial position of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. In addition, it would have been important to make progress in the area of ​​environmental decontamination as well, an aspect that is neglected in the proposals under consideration.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the scientific evidence surrounding the toxicity of mercury is well known and has been of concern for many years. As with other heavy metals, mercury poisoning is insidious, not least because exposure to this substance leads to a cumulative build-up within all creatures. As we have already heard this evening, this element is responsible for many adverse effects in human and animal health, as it affects the nervous, digestive and immune systems as well as the lungs, kidney and skin and eyes. For this reason UKIP agree with the scope of the Minamata Convention that urges countries to better manage the supply, trade and use of mercury in order to manage the health impacts of mercury exposure. We also share the objective of protecting human health and global environment from the release of mercury and its compounds by diminishing and controlling human-induced releases to air, water and land. We do recognise the sensitivity of this issue. However, we believe it should be legislated for on a national basis.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal that the Commission put to us was frankly bad. It was a proposal that did not comply with either the Minamata Convention or our own waste legislation. The Commission proposed the least rigorous option, which is permanent storage of mercury in liquid form, without treatment and exclusively in salt mines. It was a proposal apparently tailored to the current situation, despite the fact that from these warehouses - and according to written responses from the Commission - more than a thousand tons of mercury have been illegally transported to Switzerland, the Netherlands and Greece, to be sold in third countries. Fortunately, Parliament has rectified and for that I want to thank the rapporteur, Mr Eck, and all the shadow rapporteurs, especially Mr Dantin, because they have listened to technical and environmental arguments. From now on, only mercury will be temporarily stored on the surface. Definitive storage will have to be done on the surface or in salt mines and, if it is on the surface, it must be solidified and treated. The best technicians and experts in handling mercury are in my region, in the Almadén region, the largest mine in the world, and they consider that mercury should only be removed if there is a previous solidification treatment. Finally, Commissioner, I would like to invite the Commission to appear in the Committee on the Environment to explain the fraud that has occurred, as I have said before, in recent years and to give us reliable figures and tell us about the steps taken , and if there have been sanctions. And also, that you explain to us if you are finally going to authorize the treatment of mercury in its reversion to mercury sulfide in Switzerland, because in Switzerland the European Union has no power to control. Commissioner, I am sorry to express myself in these terms, but please understand. I come from Almadén. From a region that was rich and prosperous thanks to mercury and that today it is depressed and depopulated while seeing that far away they are getting richer with the mercury that has come out of their mines and that is being sold illegally.

name: Susanne Melior (S&D).
text: - Mister President! Our colleagues have already pointed out that mercury is a highly toxic material - it damages nerves, liver, lungs, our immune system, eyes, teeth and also our largest organ, the skin, and the consequences for us are very, very dramatic. Mercury is also very long-lived and is widely distributed through the air and water. Hence there is bioaccumulation, bio magnification, and there are great problems associated with them. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his very ambitious report and I also share his assessment that we could certainly have got a little more out of it. I think, however, that we are on the right track, and my colleagues have already pointed out that it is a matter of ratifying the Minimata Agreement signed by 140 countries in 2013 and thus finally getting it off the ground. We have the results of the trialogue here, and I believe that, despite everything, one can say: It deserves our approval. The results achieved in the trialogue are planned for a long time until a complete stop for the highly toxic mercury, which is only planned for 2030. You can't quite satisfy. However, we as S&D will agree with the result and still believe that ambitious action is necessary in the Member States in order to make faster progress, because pregnant women and babies in particular must be clearly protected. Our colleagues have already pointed this out as well.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Restricting the use of mercury as much as possible and thus fully implementing the Minamata Convention of the United Nations - that is the aim of this regulation. I am convinced that we have succeeded in doing this. Let me remind you that in 2013 the European Union signed this convention in order to reduce the harmful effects of mercury. The aim was to only use mercury where there are absolutely no suitable alternatives. As some colleagues have already mentioned, there are a few exceptions for which no suitable replacement has yet been found. One that my colleague Meissner has already mentioned is in the area of ​​homeopathic and anthroposophic medicines. They contain the tiniest amounts of mercury as an active ingredient or starting material, and this is still necessary for certain forms of therapy. A certain amount of mercury is not yet replaceable. It is important to me that they can still be manufactured in Europe. It is clear that companies must ensure that their use does not pose a risk to humans or the environment. It is of course also necessary to carry out research so that we will be able to do without the use of mercury altogether in the future and that at some point we can make it completely replaceable. I would like to thank all colleagues who have worked on this, especially our shadow rapporteur Michel Dantin. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Mr. Representative!I have heard from many, but especially from you, that here the European Union is doing only what our international commitments absolutely justify.Although you also hinted that there could be a little maybe more.But I respectfully ask that in your opinion, if only e.g.from a public health point of view, what would it cost for the dental intervention of the European population to remove amalgam and replace it with others?

name: Norbert Lins (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.–Thank you for asking what it would cost if you stopped using mercury.I don't know the exact numbers.However, it is clear - and colleague Liese made it clear beforehand in the discussion - that a discussion is taking place in science and that the majority opinion is still that we are not yet in a position, for example in dental treatment,to forego amalgam entirely.I would like to repeat what I said before, that I also see it that way in the field of homeopathic anthroposophic medicine.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Dear colleagues! You have all said it today: Mercury is a dangerous substance! Yes, it is in fact one of the most dangerous environmental toxins we have here on the planet. It is a substance that, even in small amounts, can cause damage to both health and the environment, and one of the most serious injuries that can be found is probably when fetuses get damage to the nervous system with the risk that the children when they are born , both get slower learning and slower development. These are serious consequences for human health that we are talking about here. And we also know that mercury accumulates in the food chain, and that is very, very serious for our environment. Therefore, it is really good that with the agreement that is now in place, we can get the Minamata Convention approved, and that we can tighten up the rules that exist in the EU. That is why I support the proposal that is on the table. Personally, I would have liked to have seen us go further, e.g. had also introduced an actual ban on the use of mercury in dental care, but there was no support for it. When I still support the proposal and the agreement that is in place, it is because it opens up the possibility for the Member States to go further than what is in the agreement. So we are talking about minimum rules, and I think it is important that we, on the part of Parliament, put pressure on the Member States to take advantage of the possibility in the agreement to go beyond what is in the agreement. But I support the proposal as it stands.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues on the compromise that I am prepared to support. I very much welcome the fact that we will be voting on the draft regulation tomorrow, because, for example, the handling of a dangerous substance such as mercury is exactly the story of having uniform rules for the whole of the EU, so that each country does not address this issue separately. . This is in the interests of both public health protection and the producers themselves, companies that use mercury in their production, and it is also in the interests of legal certainty for all EU citizens. I very much welcome the fact that the final proposal is different from what the European Commission has put forward, and that it addresses a number of issues that were not originally addressed in the European Commission. On the one hand, health must be protected, mercury use must be reduced and eliminated in the future. On the other hand, it is necessary to set such rules that will not harm companies, industrial companies that use mercury in production processes, in short, mercury comes together in their technologies. Jobs also need to be protected, and this adjustment, with its transitional periods, clearly allows entrepreneurs to adjust their technologies, their production and to stop producing or using mercury in the future, without this leading to the closure of production processes and job losses. I also welcome the compromise on dental amalgam. It seems very balanced to me. In the first place, vulnerable groups, children, pregnant women must be protected and amalgam must be eliminated in the future. Here is the important role of the Commission: to present a plan to eliminate mercury in dentistry in the future.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, the cumulative effects of mercury have been documented to harm the human body and there are no recognized levels of safety. Even the indirect release of any amount into the environment is unacceptable due to its toxicity and long-term duration. It must be replaced with appropriate and satisfactory options, investing in alternative production processes. Restrictions on trade in mercury-containing products are imposed, and at the same time third countries that have a processing industry or process mercury-containing products should be assisted by introducing innovative and best practices. The elimination of mercury use and the inactivation of harmful residues are properly accompanied by traceability criteria, waste recycling, landfill management and remediation of contaminated areas. Member States must do their utmost to support the efficient implementation of the ambitious proposals. To summarize: There are no safe limits for mercury and action must be taken immediately.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - So mercury emissions are recognized as a global threat that justifies action at local, regional, national and global levels, as well as measures, and this report we are adopting today must be seen as part of a global effort to reduce riskdue to exposure to mercury.I would also like to draw attention here to the mercury program under the United Nations Environment Program.Of course, there are also many environmental and social problems associated with this, which are the result of the closure of mines on the one hand, and the release and infiltration of this mercury into the environment on the other.I support the proposal of the report that is on our table, especially regarding key instruments and protections also regarding dental amalgams, waste, use, export and, of course, appropriate protection mechanisms.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Dear President, I would certainly like to strongly support this report because it seeks to reduce the use of mercury, to regulate the use of mercury, especially in the most sensitive part when it comes to children and pregnant women.However, I asked for the floor because I once asked the Commission what the Commission had to know about living in the Mediterranean.Living on the Adriatic, I am particularly interested in the Adriatic Sea, but I am interested in the whole Mediterranean because these children, these pregnant women and we all eat fish from the Adriatic and the Mediterranean, for which many studies show that tuna and shark in particular contain quite high levels of mercury.So, in this context, I ask the Commission to see how it will further analyze the situation and nutrition of the population that lives and uses fish for its own diet.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, after the signing of the Minamata Convention under the UNEP aiming to control the use of mercury, this ban on mercury fillings for children and pregnant women is a natural next step. However, in my opinion. Member States must go further and prohibit all dental amalgam. I welcome the inclusion in this report of the mention that national plans on phasing out amalgam should be made publicly available and sent to the Commission by 1 July 2019. Moreover, new products and processes containing or needing mercury should only be authorised when an assessment of the risk and the benefits demonstrates a significant environmental and health benefit. Finally, there should be a ban on the use of amalgam in vulnerable populations. Limitations on certain exports and industrial processes are also big achievements.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, mercury is a threat to human health and the environment, both in the European Union and on the rest of the world. Scientific evidence unequivocally proves the acute toxicity of mercury, an element that can not be destroyed or destroyed. With the wind, this heavy metal spreads, as a result of which it accumulates in the food chain. European scientists estimate that 1.5 to 2 million children in the European Union are born each year exposed to banned levels of methylmercury. Also, 200,000 children are exposed annually to levels above the maximum limit set by the World Health Organization. The European Union must solve the problem of mercury. It must reduce emissions from coal-fired power plants in Germany, which produce more than 5 tonnes of mercury each year. Also measures must be taken for dental amalgams, batteries, lamps and waste.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the widespread use of mercury throughout the world poses serious health and environmental problems. Since the industrial revolution the amount of mercury present in the sea has tripled due to the polluting activities of man and there are many pathologies related to the exposure and ingestion of mercury, with very serious complications for the brain, lungs, kidneys and immune system . The text that we will approve will integrate in a single legal act the obligations deriving from the Minamata Convention, which have not yet been transposed into EU law, and will allow it to take part in its first conference scheduled in Geneva. There remains regret for the non-acceptance in the trialogue of some proposals put forward by Parliament, such as the ban on the use of mercury in dental amalgams for children under 15 and for women in the breastfeeding phase and total ban on dental amalgams starting in 2022. The world needed a more ambitious Union approach to the Minamata process.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the support many of you expressed and would like to make the following remarks concerning some of the points you addressed in this interesting debate. On Ms Ayuso’s question: the mercury export fraud was due to illegal activities by a German company. It has been closed and the responsible people are being prosecuted now. The Commission has intervened too, where possible, to prevent the exported mercury from being used and to ensure that it is taken back to Germany. On homeopathy, the regulation does not prohibit the use of mercury in homeopathy. On the proposal that the EU should prohibit fully the use of dental amalgam, the Commission’s scientific committee concluded that there was no evidence of risks to the health of patients from the use of dental amalgam. However, the Commission supports the precautionary prohibition of amalgam use for dental care of children and pregnant and breastfeeding women. This prohibition has been included in the regulation. Furthermore, reducing the use of mercury is beneficial for the environment and the requirement for Member States to draw up national plans on the phasing-down of dental amalgam should make a significant contribution towards this objective. As required by the regulation, the Commission will launch a feasibility study on the full prohibition of dental amalgam and report back to the legislator by mid-2020. Allow me to conclude by saying that I am confident after today’s debate that you will massively support the new mercury regulation in your vote tomorrow. This will confirm that the EU is firmly on track to become the first mercury-free economy and will set an example for our international partners.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Thank you for your comments and for your strong support for the report. We have taken an important step in the right direction. But let me conclude by saying something that this House, and especially the Council, is all too happy to forget: environmental policy is social policy; it influences economic development and the quality of life of all people. It must be the task of environmental policy to give ecological concerns a weighty voice. It must ensure that the principle of shared responsibility is not marginalized by particularly vocal or financially strong interest groups. For future debates and decisions on environmental issues and issues, I appeal to you, dear colleagues, to finally turn your back on the old battle slogans - such as advocating environmental issues is anti-technology, endangers jobs and is an obstacle to economic development To understand environmental policy as sustainability policy. For the future, I hope that the Minamata process will continue to put pressure on national governments and will further reduce the contamination of the soil, the sites, and the use in dentistry and industrial processes.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 14 March 2017.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Sergio Gaetano Cofferati, on behalf of the Legal Affairs Committee, proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2007/36 / EC as regards encouraging the long-term commitment ofshareholders and Directive 2013/34 / EU as regards certain elements of the corporate governance report (COM (2014) 0213 - C7-0147 / 2014 - 2014/0121 (COD)) (A8-0158 / 2015)

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner, tomorrow we will vote in plenary on the agreement reached in the trialogue which took place over the past few months. I believe that the text we approved has strong positive elements and objectively represents a very important step forward in terms of the regulatory definition of corporate governance in the European Union. The discussion was very long - the Commission's text was presented three years ago - it took all this time to reach a widely shared solution due to the sensitivity of the subject and the elements of different legislation that we had to deal with. : the commitment was necessary but I believe it has reached a point of conclusion which will benefit the Union. However, this result would not have been possible without the support of Parliament's Secretariat and without the commitment of many of my colleagues, starting with Olle Ludvigsson who was the rapporteur for the ECON committee. I also thank the shadow rapporteurs of the various political groups, with whom we have sometimes heatedly discussed but who have followed this dossier competently and with a great sense of responsibility. Now, this positive result will allow us to take further steps forward. The goal was very simple to describe, a little more complex and difficult to achieve. It was and still has to pass from a condition in which companies and their managers often invest to have short-term returns, to have personal advantages that do not correspond to the interests of the community. For this reason, it is important to incentivize the exact opposite: to give transparency to everything that investors need and to ensure that companies make choices that guarantee a profit for them, but above all benefits for the community, looking at the medium and long term. This was the logic that Jacques Delors had introduced with the 1993 White Paper: we kept it as a reference this logic and that text of great cultural as well as economic value. There are some aspects that I would like to quickly underline: tighter controls and full transparency on the remuneration of directors of listed companies, starting with the so-called say-on-pay, i.e. the vote by shareholders on the directors' remuneration policy and on the annual report. on its application; the same transparency for institutional investors and asset managers, which will help guide the action of these players towards a more targeted approach to medium and long-term returns; the obligations of transparency, the red thread that contains the whole directive also for proxy advisors; and then the right for companies to identify their shareholders. Finally, still transparency and control regarding transactions with related parties. Everything that can be seen and interpreted is a great advantage, both for those who decide to invest and for those who will benefit from the positive effects of these companies. There is one last thing I would like to quickly underline: we had introduced legislation on country-by-country reporting into the text in committee. The reminder that came from that discussion allowed the commission to present a specific text which is now being examined by the ECON commission. I think this is right: we made this effort together, this responsible choice, to give the regulatory system this advantage too. The conclusion will be close and I imagine also positive as regards this further element of a sound fiscal policy in Europe.

name: Olle Ludvigsson
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. - Mr President! There is no doubt that corporate governance in Europe can be improved. Everyone wins. The agreement we have reached in tripartite negotiations is generally very positive in this regard. In short, this means that we have a more stable framework in place, which promotes increased openness and transparency for listed companies and investors as well as a more long-term perspective. This is extremely important. With regard to the work of institutional investors and asset managers, the negotiations have presented and emphasized the importance of maintaining strong and clear provisions on increased transparency. The discussion with the Council has not been entirely easy, but the result is still a step forward. While I regret that we were forced to give up the country-by-country reporting requirement, it is gratifying that we still managed to put the issue on the agenda with the Commission's proposal on just this. Having said that, I hope that tomorrow we can adopt the agreement by a broad majority. Active corporate governance with increased transparency and other measures that promote shareholder arrangements and make it easier for shareholders to exercise influence, I see as only positive. A big thank you to Cofferati and to all the shadow rapporteurs who have participated in the work.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Cofferati, all the shadow rapporteurs, the Slovak Presidency and the previous presidencies for their hard work and the excellent collaboration on this dossier. The journey was not always easy. However, thanks to the determination and willingness to compromise by all the parties involved, a political agreement was reached in December last year. It is time to adopt this important directive, which will foster more long—term, transparent and sustainable capital markets in Europe. The compromise proposal on the table today represents a balanced outcome. Let me refer to some of the main aspects. First, I welcome the agreed approach concerning transparency of institutional investors, asset managers and proxy advisers. It will encourage institutional investors and asset managers to look at the long-term perspective and also consider environmental, social and governance factors when they invest. This is what our economy needs. Second, the proposed solutions on remuneration will ensure more transparency and better oversight of directors’ pay, not only for shareholders, but also for companies and the whole society. How directors are paid influences how they conduct business. Third, the proposed compromise will also ensure more efficient communication throughout the investment chain. In this way it will enable listed companies and their shareholders to communicate more efficiently. Therefore it is a crucial step to encourage more shareholder engagement. We also need safeguards against abusive related-party transactions in order to attract more foreign investors to our capital markets. I note that the level of ambition in this respect has been reduced from what the Commission initially aimed at. Nevertheless, I believe that overall the compromise would clearly improve the current regulatory framework for related-party transactions across the EU. We need this directive to enhance Europe’s competitiveness. It builds on lessons learned from the financial crisis and aims to foster sustainable growth. It respects Member States’ corporate governance systems and keeps pace with the latest developments at international level. We need to show that the EU is able to deliver on this.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Dear Commissioner, Colleagues, Whenever we conduct a debate on the functioning of enterprises, companies on the European market, we must bear in mind the basic elements that cannot be abandoned, that is, ensuring stable operations for our European companies allowing for the development and increasing the number of jobs, and secondly, on ensuring the competitiveness of our companies against companies from other markets. This is what is happening in the world of globalization, there is no exception to it. Therefore, any action of this type must be primarily aimed at adopting instruments that will strengthen it, not weaken it. The work on the directive on long-term shareholder engagement initially went in the wrong direction. Most of all, it was hampered by the attempts to include country by country reporting in this directive. Only when it was possible to isolate this problem into a completely different legislative solution, could this work be carried out with impetus and we could focus on what is most important, i.e. on the proper functioning of capital markets and on ensuring transparency in the remuneration policy. This transparency is, of course, of great importance from one point of view: a company that is in a weak financial condition cannot award its directors unbelievably high remuneration because it is socially unacceptable. But only and only such decisions that strengthen companies can we accept. This has been achieved in lengthy negotiations, and we will therefore be voting in favor of the result tomorrow. Thanks to everyone who worked on this for a long, long time.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! First of all, I would like to thank our rapporteur Sergio Cofferati for two and a half years of hard work and, above all, for the result that has been achieved and which our group also supports. The revision of the directive aims to overcome the previously insufficient involvement of shareholders in company decisions, to increase transparency in the exercise of voting rights by shareholders and to achieve better control of corporate governance by strengthening shareholders' rights, and this is exactly what will be the case in the future . In future, shareholders will be better informed about the companies in which they invest and also be able to vote on the remuneration of managers. And for the first time in the history of European company law, the role of stakeholders is also recognized - especially those employees who are not shareholders. But I would like to underline at this point: There is one very central point that really needs to be resolved. It must be enforced that companies put the cards on the table when it comes to their profits. Companies should finally pay taxes where they make profits. For our group, country-specific reporting on tax-relevant company data is a key issue in the fight against tax avoidance. We'll stay tuned here. The race for tax avoidance must be stopped - that is what citizens expect from us.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: on behalf of the ECR Group.- Mister President!This discussion is also about the payment of managers.And if politicians now think they have to decide what managers earn, then I can see that they will soon also decide what football players or actors or directors of television companies will earn.Of course, there is always a contradiction between transparency on the one hand and the desire for privacy on the other.That is also a right of managers.And in fact, of course, there is also the right of owners to determine how to pay managers.And so I am convinced that it would be best if we now at large corporations have the shareholders decide what the managers pay and what the managers get, and not just the boards of directors.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Cofferati for the great work he has done. Today, we are discussing a proposal to revise the current Shareholders' Rights Directive. The proposal aims to address shortcomings in the administration and management of listed companies. In practice, this will be about 10,000 of the largest companies listed on European stock exchanges. With this proposal, we want to involve shareholders more in the events in the companies in which they have invested. We want shareholders to be able to exercise proper control over the management of companies and not let managers often take short-term and excessive risks. Furthermore, and I consider it important, we want shareholders to be able to decide on the company's corporate remuneration policy. Currently, only a few Member States allow shareholders to intervene in directors' salaries. We require that the amount of executive remuneration be approved by the General Meeting. According to statistics, only 15 Member States today require the publication of remuneration policy data and 11 the publication of directors' salaries. I hope that with this proposal, we have only taken the first step towards greater transparency in the field of company law.

name: Pascal Durand
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, your words have illustrated a Europe that we love, Europe such as it should continue to build, that is to say this search for balance between a Europe which carries economic force, an economic vision and which at the same time does not consider that on all subjects, regulation would be a bad thing. A Europe that regulates in a positive direction, a Europe that recognizes that shameless financialization of economic activity can undermine a medium and long-term vision - and this was very well said by Mr Cofferati. Our industry was also built because captains of industry - as we said at the time - had a medium and long term vision for several generations. This is often supported by small businesses and SMEs and this is what this text is intended to reintroduce at the level of large companies. This legislation reminds us of something simple: transparency - you used that word, Commissioner, and you were right to use it - must not stop at the threshold of large companies. I understand very well the desire of a certain number, both of leaders and at the same time of politicians, to ensure that the company does not weigh too much on the company that would prevent it from being able to develop. I hear that argument, but for all that, absolute freedom, absolute deregulation, does not and does not bear fruit. In general, we must find this balance between this need for the medium and long term and that of the financiers, to have very short-term returns on the investments they produce. This is the work that has been done, this is your will and that of Parliament to redirect a large number of financial investments towards the real economy. I will not go into detail since it has been very well explained previously.On the points of transparency that we have acquired, I will specify, as an ecologist, that I am delighted that the issue of environmental and social risks is also taken into account and constitutes a new guide and a new future for the European Union..

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, transparency, control and sustainability. These are the key words of the company law reform we are discussing today. It is very important, in our opinion, that the remuneration of managers of listed companies is subject to the control of the shareholders' meeting which, among other things, will be able to formulate its assessments, not only taking into account the long-term performance of the company but also of the commitments undertaken regarding corporate social responsibility. All this, together with the other provisions regarding transparency measures for institutional investors and asset managers, who must undertake to describe their relationship with the companies in which they invest, will only increase commitment and long-term sustainability. equity investment in this type of company. We regret that the compromise reached in the trialogue provided for the excerpt of the country-by-country reporting: but we are nevertheless convinced that the excellent work of the Parliament's negotiating team has really pushed the Commission to present an ad hoc proposal for a directive, which we hope will be approved as soon as possible.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! In view of the circumstances that existed in this report, especially from the EPP point of view, I would also like to thank our rapporteur Tadeusz Zwiefka very warmly for his commitment and effort in what, from our point of view, was much bureaucratic, which perhaps also here in this report partly did not belong in, but then it came out again. That is why it was not acceptable to us in the Legal Affairs Committee at that time as the EPP Group what was there in this report, and that is why it went far beyond what we had as a proposal from the Commission. We first have to see where it all comes from. We had this decisive experience of the financial market crisis. That was a very decisive event and it continues to have this effect today. That is why it is right today to speak of the long-term nature of systems, of the transparency that we need there, of the competitiveness that you also mentioned. That is why it makes sense to deal with the remuneration as well, because we often had to use tax funds to absorb something that did not affect those responsible. That's why it's sensible. But this question of tax avoidance and country by county reporting should not and should not have been the subject of this directive - so it was a good thing that the Commission resolved it accordingly - we have our own instrument to make it clear again here, too, that tax avoidance should not take place in Europe. But it shouldn't have gone in here. Of course we have various things about which we are particularly proud that afterwards the excessive bureaucracy was avoided and that we then have this transparency in all these things.
