That is why it has now become a report that can be approved and that we are happy to support.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Colleagues, in my country the average CEO earns in three days what the average worker will earn in a year. CEOs’ pay has almost doubled over the last 10 years, while real pay for the average worker has stagnated. Dealing with this excessive remuneration is not anti-business. A survey of members of the Institute of Directors showed SMEs felt high pay in some big businesses was harming the reputation of all businesses. So it is great that this directive takes action to improve pay transparency, as well as improving many other areas of corporate governance. Brexit cannot be used as an excuse for progress on this issue to be rolled back, particularly in Britain. The EU’s cap on bankers’ bonuses was challenged by the British Government but largely supported by the British people, just as they support action to make CEO pay more accountable. The message this directive sends must be heeded across the EU and in Britain, including after Brexit. Congratulations again to the rapporteur.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Theresa May has made great theatre of her political will to restrain corporate excess, but so far we have seen little action. As research suggests that more than a third of big companies fail to comply with the UK’s currently voluntary code, she might do well to look to Europe for a progressive blueprint. This legislation improves the long-term commitment of shareholders in listed companies and strengthens the link between directors’ pay and performance, showing the EU’s progress towards a more transparent and responsible economy. Shareholders will have a say on directors’ pay. Details of how their pay has increased will be published so that it can be compared with the pay of employees and the company’s performance, something that last year’s Whitehall proposals tiptoed around. Disappointingly, public country-by-country reporting was dropped from the final legislation despite support from the Parliament and Commission. As Greens we will push hard to ensure that this most important weapon in our ongoing battle against corporate tax avoidance is advanced as rapidly as possible.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, let me begin by thanking all my colleagues in the Committee on Legal Affairs, in particular the rapporteur, Mr Cofferati, who have contributed to an acceptable compromise in the trialogue. The result is a good response to the need to support long-term strategic investors. The financial crisis of 2008-2012 taught us about this. Personally, I voted against the original text of the report in the JURI Committee, because I believe that the original text deviated too far from the model that we should apply in the EU, and that is the model of the social market economy. For me, the social market economy is an ideal model in which the rights of both employees and employers are guaranteed. A model that is neither wild capitalism without rules nor over-regulated socialism. I therefore consider it good that the resulting text does not contain a section on so-called country-by-country reporting, which does not belong there in the same way as similar other sections. Therefore, in tomorrow's vote, I can support the agreed proposal as it emerged from the trialogue.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: - First of all, thanks to Sergio Cofferati and the other colleagues for this result. The question now is whether there are also good shareholders, because this directive gives the shareholders more powers to determine the remuneration of top executives. I distrust the system of bonuses, but at least let it be so that the reward pays off in the long run. That requires good shareholders. Yes, there can be. Many investors invest money for us, such as insurance companies and pension funds. It is up to these investors to break with the quarterly culture in companies and opt for a long-term perspective. Countries can and must support them by strengthening the bond between shareholders and companies, for example through loyalty dividends or in other ways. After all, Europe deserves companies that are concerned about the long term, where the rewards for directors and employees are in line with each other and who dare to opt for People Planet Profit, because value is more than just profit.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Much has already been said. On behalf of the EPP Group - also thanking Mr Zwiefka - I would like to make it clear once again that we all agree that sustainable corporate policy and the long-term orientation of corporate decisions in Europe have produced strong companies, and we have an interest in ensuring that it stays that way . And that is what connects us, I believe, across the political group. I am also very happy to tell you that we spoke for a long time about this in the Internal Market Committee with Mr Cofferati - it is a connecting element. But unfortunately we also had to ensure in this guideline that the not really shareholder law issues of country by country reporting - Mr Voss has already explained it - are resolved. We managed to do that, and I'm very grateful for that. The third thing I would like to say: Of course, we have a great interest in granting the shareholders who own the company more decision-making rights. In the Commission's original proposal, we may not have been able to distinguish so much between the dualistic and the one-tier principle. But I believe that the results that came out in the end are definitely to be welcomed and have also been well reflected, and I am therefore also grateful that we have succeeded in defining and anchoring this. And the last point that is raised again and again: Of course, we have an interest in fair and appropriate rewards for CEOs and managing directors who perform an important task, but we cannot uniformly stipulate in Europe what the minimum wage and what the middle wage is and what the maximum wage should be. This is where the Member States are asked. And I believe that this - regardless of whether it is advisory or binding - will ultimately be decided by the shareholders' committees can - is a good solution.Overall, I am very satisfied for my part and thank everyone who contributed to it.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement reached on the directive is an important step forward on the subject of corporate governance. After two years of negotiations, we have European legislation which, for the first time, does not just mention shareholders but recognizes the role of workers and other stakeholders, ensures controls and provides for the vote of shareholders on the remuneration policy of company directors listed, also on the basis of results and taking into account corporate social responsibility, and introduces greater transparency on social and environmental impacts. It is a pity, of course, that the part on country-by-country reporting has not already passed but it is precisely and also thanks to the commitment of Parliament and the rapporteur that the Commission has finally presented a specific proposal in this regard. This is still an insufficient proposal, as it provides for high thresholds and the reporting obligation for activities outside the EU only in aggregate form; therefore it needs to be improved and approved as soon as possible to truly combat tax evasion and avoidance on a global level.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Mister President! We see it now: everyone is on the whole happy. We did a good job on the shareholder rights policy. I would especially like to thank the rapporteur, Sergio Cofferati. We Social Democrats here in this House have been fighting for a long time to ensure that there is more transparency in European companies, that companies act sustainably, that they make long-term decisions and not just have the short rip-offs in mind - because that was ultimately the reason for the Financial crisis. We are now seeing a paradigm shift here that we have due to the modified shareholder approach to the shareholder rights directive. Ultimately, greater responsibility is to be assumed by the owners. Of course, it is particularly important to me that Sergio Cofferati negotiated in such a way that this issue of transparency, namely through public country-by-country reporting - that is, country-by-country reporting that is supposed to bring even more transparency - was finally able to prevail and was eliminated we now have the opportunity to include this result in the accounting guidelines. However, it cannot be emphasized often enough that it is a great success that employees are also mentioned as the most important stakeholders in European company law - in other words, the stakeholder approach has now found its way. That is something that we should campaign for here in this House, that it should continue to do so and that the approach really followed is that companies should act for the long term because they are part of this society and should also fulfill their social obligations.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, insufficient shareholder participation and the lack of adequate transparency are the main shortcomings of corporate governance in Europe. The excessive focus on high returns in the short term leads, in the medium and long term, to planning deficiencies, insufficient investments and suboptimal results. I support the introduction of a modern and efficient corporate governance framework for European companies, investors and employees which at the same time gives a more transparent and more influential role to minority shareholders. Greater transparency needs the activities of large companies, the profits made, the taxes paid and the subsidies received. If investors are more involved and their commitment focused on the medium and long term, the end users, institutional investors but also the companies themselves will benefit. I congratulate the rapporteur Cofferati on his excellent work and I agree with him that tomorrow's vote will certainly not solve the problem but it certainly represents a reasonable step in the right direction.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Cofferati on his report, because he really raises the issues that concern corporate governance today. First of all, as others have said, transparency in the operation and management of companies is necessary, because shareholders need to have an idea of ​​what is happening to executives. We have seen huge rewards for the executives themselves to get, to make these rewards for themselves, to set goals that often do not serve the business itself but serve to increase their own rewards, that is, we now have a serious problem with the golden boys that exist in big business. In addition, it is important that investors, who put their money, have an image and knowledge. Many times they are institutional investors. We have insurance funds that put their money and should invest in companies that show social and environmental sensitivity.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, this directive proposes to promote greater involvement of shareholders in long-term strategies, but, in view of the problem of the myopia of investors, which undermines sustainable growth strategies, a purely cosmetic directive is created, which will solve absolutely nothing. This directive takes the problem to the contrary, putting this problem on shareholders, when it is these same shareholders who want short-term returns. In most cases, shareholders do not even know companies because they see companies as a mere instrument of savings and financial profitability and nothing more. If they want to go against the strategies of companies, which are too focused on short-term gains, then it is necessary to involve the parties that are truly interested in the long term, it is necessary to involve the workers, the local and regional institutions that must be involved in the discussion and implementation of these strategies and also in wage policy, where one could have gone much further by imposing a cap on disparities, but that would naturally go too far for those who think that democracy should stay at the doors of the company.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - So this proposal before us certainly represents an important step forward, which is necessary, and the question is whether it is sufficient.Of course, it also focuses on the participation of shareholders in joint stock companies, which should be encouraged to be more active, to participate in corporate governance, but they will not be able to do so unless greater transparency, greater transparency and therefore responsibility of those whothey are taking decisions that a couple of years ago dragged almost the whole of Europe into a financial crisis, also due to taking on large obligations without taking into account the risks in the field of financial mathematics.Therefore, I think that it is necessary to provide a greater possibility for control, a greater possibility also for establishing responsibility, and therefore greater transparency for the actions of shareholders, in order to actually realize what is also the purpose of joint stock companies.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the report clarifies many things about corporate governance.The changes bring efficiency and effectiveness not only to companies but also to the community. Transparency has increased and this benefits both shareholders and the community.The involvement of shareholders will benefit all parties involved.The clarification of the terms will lead to the correct application of the improvements made to this directive.I want to congratulate the rapporteur on the final text.I would also like to point out that the new text also provides for the protection of data on the identity of shareholders.I believe that corporate ethics and equity are ensured between the director, directors, investors, shareholders and the community.We need corporate governance, but also social responsibility.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is so important to address this very important subject of corporate governance. In the last years, we have tried to address this issue from a different angle. It is time now to promote this subject of integration within European Union policies and future directives. In fact, long-term shareholder engagement is a policy that should support the investors and shareholders investing in European Union economies.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the debate has shown that we all share an understanding of the main goals of this directive, namely more transparency and more investor responsibility so that investors and directors consider the long-term consequences of their actions and also ensure the sustainability of EU capital markets. The debate also showed that we are in agreement that the directive contains the way in which this should be implemented in an efficient and proportionate way. So I would like to thank you for the positive debate you had here and I strongly encourage you to adopt the compromise text tomorrow.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: speaker. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank my colleagues and the Commissioner for the comments made and for this very broad sharing of the proposal that we have built together. It took a long time, but this was because the merit was complex: we had to discuss with the Luxembourg presidency, then the Dutch, then the Slovakian to come to a conclusion with the Maltese one. This speaks volumes about how complex the set of themes we had to unravel was. I would like to point out just a few things quickly. I think that the political and institutional system should not work to place restrictive constraints on businesses. Sometimes they are needed but our prevailing behavior must be to give stimuli and incentives and I believe that in the text that we will approve tomorrow, so I hope, all this is very clear, just as I believe that managers must be helped to adopt positive behaviors in their companies. , not to engage in financial speculation, as has often happened, to the detriment of the capital invested and the people who work in those companies. Again, I would like to reassure my colleague who fears that politics may also decide on the remuneration of actors and singers. This is not the case, least of all in this text: politics does not decide; it will be up to the shareholders to decide, which unfortunately does not always happen, with serious damage to the whole structure that generates wealth, for forms and channels that are not the best and most desirable ones. Therefore, the function of politics is a precise function but it also has a positive character if the conclusions are those that are in the written text. The last point concerns country-by-country reporting: I think it is right not to have the solution on reporting in this text and that its placement in the text of the new directive is the best thing. But, let's say quite frankly, when we started there discussion, that Commission text was not there and if we had not discussed among ourselves, even animatedly, the new Commission proposal would not have been born.We obtained a result thanks also to the sense of balance, which did not lead to breakdowns but a little courage and a little determination, which was not lacking in the relationship between all the speakers, starting with the shadow speakers.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 14 March 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – The proposal of the European Commission aspires to enhance the influential role of minority shareholders in listed companies. Their higher engagement and stronger influence on decision-making processes would secure the long-run orientation of those shareholders. As a result, the companies would prioritise the long-term concerns over accelerating the profits and returns in the short term in order to please the demand of shareholders. I welcome the initiative and I believe it shall be considered as a substantial part of the legislation dealing with the involvement of stakeholders in corporate governance. Nevertheless, I hope that addressing involvement of stakeholders other than shareholders in corporate governance, such as employees, consumers or local communities, will be high on the agenda of the European Commission in the near future. The well-being of any company requires respect and engagement of all stakeholders involved. In reaction to Article 3f of the proposal, addressing the engagement policy, I am convinced the basic transparency shall not be voluntary. The institutional investors and asset managers ought to be transparent about the application of their engagement policies. Furthermore, regarding Article 9a, I would suggest an obligation for companies to declare and disclose the ratio between the remuneration of directors and employees.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: signed up.- The financial crisis that erupted in 2008 also exposed the mistakes made by many institutional investors, including pension funds and insurance companies, by engaging in financial speculation and short-term interest-bearing investments.The draft directive is welcome, as it brings more rigor in this important area of the capital market, requires greater transparency for institutional investors, by correctly informing shareholders about the business model adopted, oriented towards their long-term interest.This draft directive also obliges institutional investors to rethink the incentive system for asset managers in order to promote long-term investments and a better correlation with the structure of obligations.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Ernest Urtasun, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2014-2015 (2016/2249(INI)) (A8-0046/2017), – the report by Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on the application of Council Directive 2004/113/EC implementing the principle of equal treatment between men and women in the access to and supply of goods and services (2016/2012(INI)) (A8—0043/2017), and – the report by Clare Moody, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on EU funds for gender equality (2016/2144(INI)) (A8—0033/2017).

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: speaker. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs who have been working with me on the report. The truth is that it has been a pleasure. I think we have done a good exercise in analyzing above all the state of gender equality at the level of the European Union. I also want to thank - and I want to mention it especially - to the European Institute for Gender Equality, because without them, without their help, it would have been much more difficult to also make this report - through all the analyzes they do the data they collect, the index they develop, which I think is extremely positive—; from this point of view, well, I also want to thank you. This report aims to send out a very clear message, which is that, judging by the data and the concrete analysis of certain indicators, we are blocked, when we do not take steps back, in terms of gender equality at the level of the European Union. And this is the first thing we must recognize because this is not installed in the public debate, nor in the policy debate. And I think it's important that we say it. If we take the pension gap indicator, it is not just that we are still at 40%, it is that in half of the Member States that gap has increased. If we take the wage gap, we are at 16.2, which is practically the same level as we had in 2012; we have not practically advanced. In terms of political participation, progress in recent years is only 6%. We are going very little by little, even in this house, where we have gone from 30 to 37. Yes, there is progress, but it is very, very scarce. And then the violence data. Not only because of the cases that we repeatedly see in many of our Member States, but also because of the data, and in this case the report refers to the study and survey of the European Agency for Fundamental Rights, based in Vienna, which thus revealed that 33% of women who acknowledge having been victims of an episode of violence at some point in their life, and 55% who acknowledge having been victims of an episode of sexual harassment at some point in their life. Therefore, I think we must recognize that this data is not good. And the question that we have asked ourselves and that we have shared with the other speakers is how the institutions are responding to this question. And it is true - and this is not only at the level of the European Union, but also at the level of many Member States - that the equality agenda is quite blocked. We have had times when there was a lot of ambition in this matter - even here, legislative, and in many Member States - and now this is no longer the case. And, of course, I have to refer to some of the things that happen, especially in the Council. The Commission withdrew the Directive on maternity leave due to blocking in the Council - although we obviously hope Commissioner Jourová, as she announced the last time, on the 24th, the new package of measures, which we are obviously ready to work to get ahead - but we also have the Directive on quotas in the boards of directors blocked, and, in the matter of violence, we are in the phase of ratifying the Istanbul Convention, and one of the things that the report asks is that it be done as quickly as possible and as quickly as possible, and that all those Member States that have not yet done so, to do so as quickly as possible. But we also do not want to stop claiming a specific instrument to combat gender violence at the level of the European Union, which we believe is absolutely indispensable. And, of course, other appeals that we make are very important. With regard to the Directive on quotas in the boards of directors, if we take the results in Norway, for example, we see that the results are very effective, and I think it would be good if the Board unblocked this dossier once and for all. Same, for example, with the pay gap.We have the announcement this week from the Icelandic Government that it will oblige all companies with more than 25 employees to explain how they ensure equal pay within the company.Well, they are measures that I think we should also be replicating at the level of the European Union.And the last thing I have to say: we want the European Commission to once again have a strategy on gender equality.I believe that this is a wish shared by this House and that is my last request.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! I, too, would like to start by thanking both the shadow rapporteurs and all the authors of the amendments for the very fruitful cooperation in drawing up my report. I am pleased that we can discuss this report and the two others in March. This is a special month: it has become the month when we are engaged in an in-depth debate on women's rights. It is also the month when all over the world there are demonstrations of women who, despite a hundred years of emancipation, still have to fight their rights in this way. And today, on the occasion of these three reports, there is an old list of outstanding issues. Both in the reports and probably in today's discussion, we will be addressing all these issues: economic issues, the right to motherhood, the right to equal pay, freedom from violence, financing equality measures and many others. Please state! As for the report I am writing on the implementation of the Directive on the access of women and men to goods and services, I would like to point out that this directive is a key point on the map of equality legislation in the European Union, as it is the first to legislate to extend the principle of equal treatment. treatment of women and men outside the labor market and transfers them into the area of ​​everyday life, which is access to goods and services. The most important success of this directive is the introduction of the same rules for women and men when calculating insurance premiums - and therefore pension contributions - in private funds. Thanks to this directive, women and men do not have to pay smaller or larger contributions just because of their gender. Insurance companies must focus on substantive criteria, such as accident history and health. And this approach aptly illustrates the principle of equal treatment of women and men in general, because the fight for equal rights is nothing more than an appeal to be guided by substantive criteria, competences, achievements instead of relying on gender stereotypes. There are also provisions in this directive - and this is what our report refers to - that deals with the protection of pregnant and maternal women. There are laws on the prohibition of sexual harassment. Much has been said about the necessity of the functioning of equality institutions in the Member States, such as ombudsmen and plenipotentiaries for equality, who implement and control the equality law in many legal acts. This directive has been successfully transposed into national law in all Member States, but its practical functioning needs to be strengthened. That is why in the report - and this is its key message - we emphasize the application of the law in practice, because, as we know, paper is patient, you can write anything on it, and in various places there are a lot of provisions regarding equal treatment of women and men, but without political will, without social awareness, without the existence of appropriate institutions and, above all, without adequate funding, this law remains dead. This is what we emphasize in this report: to apply these provisions in practice and to strengthen the equality institutions that uphold the exercise of this right. In the report, we also stress the importance of awareness of equal treatment for women and men, both among service providers and among consumers. Another important element is drawing attention to new market phenomena, such as the sharing economy, such as Uber or Airbnb. These are new phenomena, unregulated. We have to consider how and to what extent they are covered by the directive. We also speak in this report about the Istanbul Convention as a means of protection against violence and the importance of the provisions for the protection of women during motherhood.

name: Clare Moody
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the other rapporteurs for their cooperation and support in writing this document. I am proud to be presenting a report here in the plenary, following International Women’s Day, on such an important topic and I appreciate the presence of Commissioner Jourová to address – and I hope follow up on – the recommendation the Parliament makes this week. It should be a source of great pride to the EU that equality between women and men has been enshrined as a fundamental value of the Union since its very beginning. I do a lot of meetings and communications in my region and, when I talk about the support the EU provides to women, it generates an overwhelmingly positive response. There are 15 directives supporting gender equality and it is explicitly the subject of different aspects of the budget. However, we are still a long way from achieving the goal of gender equality. Indeed, if it was all sorted, there would not be a need for this report at all, and I look forward to the day when that is the case. But, in many ways and for many reasons, I fear we are in danger of slipping backwards: that gender-related issues have fallen down the political agenda and, when they are considered, a certain amount of complacency has taken hold. The report looks in detail at three specific areas: European structural and investment funds; the rights, equality and citizenship programme; and Horizon 2020. The structural and investment funds provide vital support, particularly for enabling women to work and on promoting gender equality, for example through supporting social infrastructure or women entrepreneurs. But there is not an overall strategy to make sure that there is systematic support to women in these programmes. The rights, equality and citizenship programme includes some very important areas of funding, and this support goes directly to organisations that are working in communities and have the reach and expertise to make a difference. A good example of this is the Daphne programme for combating violence against women. However, this programme also demonstrates the creeping decline in support and focus on equality. It has seen a fall in its annual funding since 2011, despite the heavy demands for this work. The Horizon 2020 Framework Programme in many ways shows the good work taking note of gender issues can achieve. It includes gender mainstreaming and provides specific support in the research process, in gender equality plans and in research content. However, these efforts need to be consistently supported by specific budget lines. In addition to these specific areas, the report looks at the budget more widely, including more recently-established work. For example, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund included gender mainstreaming in its founding principles. There are very real and particular issues for women and girls in these situations, and the essential support we provide must recognise those. Overall, I have highlighted where there has been success, but where gender mainstreaming has been – or should be – adopted has also been underlined. For us to truly make progress on ending gender inequality we must move away from assuming support for women should be siloed in particular programmes and recognise the need to focus on the impact of all EU funds.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, our 2017 Annual Report on Equality between Women and Men, which was published last week ahead of the International Women’s Day, shows that despite progress there is still a lot of work to be done. On the positive side, the report indicates that new initiatives have flourished throughout Europe in many areas, including promoting women’s participation in decision-making and economic independence and combating stereotypes and gender-based violence. On the more worrying side, it shows signs that Member States may be moving in the opposite direction and that, in some instances, we might even witness stagnation. We have already heard these worries from your speeches. In addition, the gender gaps in pay and pensions are decreasing at a glacial rate. Therefore, the EU has an important role to play to ensure continued progress in all countries, and I am glad that the European Parliament has always been an important partner in this endeavour. Further efforts are needed to close the gender gaps in employment, pay and decision-making and to fight gender-based violence. The Commission is prepared to table a comprehensive and ambitious package to improve conditions for working parents and carers, to better reconcile the work-life balance and to support the higher participation of women in the labour market. Yes, this is the package which we promised to come up with after withdrawing the maternity leave directive. If you remember, I tried to explain that the maternity leave directive had already been implemented – or rather the goals of this directive as it was proposed were implemented – in the vast majority of Member States and that we need to come with something more ambitious, also covering greater flexibility and better choices for working parents. This is the policy – not only legislation, but a comprehensive policy – which the Commission is going to propose and adopt in April. I am looking forward very much to discussions in this House on this package. Also, regarding violence, we announced for 2017 a year of focused actions to fight violence against women, and I am glad to see that many actions are taking place to follow this aim not only in the Member States, but also in this House. In addition, we remain committed to finalising the negotiations for the EU accession to the Council of Europe Istanbul Convention as soon as possible, and we call on Member States to continue their ratification processes. I can assure you that whenever I go those Member States that have not yet ratified the Convention, I am pushing them to do it as soon as possible, as this is also an important step forward in order for the EU to join the Istanbul Convention. On women on boards, we heard that it has been blocked. I can only confirm that this is true. This has been blocked in the Council. I invested a lot of energy and time into convincing those Member States that we needed to achieve the necessary majority, which is one big Member State and two smaller ones, namely Germany, which already has the law. To my great disappointment, this has been blocked. We had to open something which I call the ‘second front’, so we are now addressing – through the Diversity Charter and through many, many different individual actions – the companies directly so that they change their corporate governance policy and introduce more diversity in their managerial culture. I believe that, in the meantime, we will be able to push the Member States to change their position so that we can adopt the women on boards directive. The Commission also welcomes the report on implementing the principle of equal treatment between men and women in the access to and supply of goods and services. We will remain fully committed to ensuring gender equality in the access and provision of goods and services across the EU and will ensure that the Directive is fully and correctly implemented in all the Member States. Promoting gender equality, of course, requires the allocation of adequate funding possibilities at all levels. The 2014-2020 funding programmes already provide means of promoting gender equality and gender mainstreaming in key policy areas. Examples include the European structural and investment funds, and in particular the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund, which are key financial sources for promoting equality, for example in access to employment, career progression, reconciliation of work and private life, equal pay for equal work, labour market integration of migrant women, and investment in the provision of childcare infrastructure. Also, the rights, equality and citizenship programme co-finances national and transnational projects, promoting equal economic independence, overcoming rigid gender roles and stereotypes, and raising awareness of the gender pension gap and its causes and consequences. It also invests in preventing and combating violence against women by financing projects supporting victims of violence, training relevant professionals, raising awareness, and preventing violence linked to harmful practices. There are also other programmes, such as Horizon 2020 or the Development Cooperation Instrument, that are instrumental in promoting gender equality and gender mainstreaming. Currently gender budgeting is not applied systematically to the EU general budget. However, indicative funding for gender equality can be provided for programmes that include a clear gender equality objective and use gender equality indicators, allowing for the specification of allocated amounts. The strategic engagement for gender equality provides an overview of EUR 6.17 billion in EU-level funding allocated to achieving the targets and objectives of the strategic engagement. This report and its recommendations are very timely, as preparations for both the 2020 EU funding programmes are starting. The promise made 60 years ago in the Rome Treaty of equal treatment between women and men must continue. It is an achievable goal if we all join efforts to deliver on that promise.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs.- Mr President, I am now proposing the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the directive on equal access for women and men to goods and services.There is generally little awareness of the Directive, while addressing key issues such as equal access to employment, healthcare, education, social services and housing.In the Committee on Legal Affairs, we have noted that there are still some shortcomings in the implementation of this directive.In some cases, services are provided only to persons of the same sex or different prices are charged for the same services.Special attention is required for pregnant women or parents and carers of young children.We still have a lot of work to do in the area of gender, for example we have to focus on equal pay for the same work or the equalization of pensions.There is still room for improvement.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Mr President, despite the fact that the European Union is fully committed to gender equality, and that we recognize it as one of our fundamental values ​​and objectives, the effort remains insufficient. Different studies show that in the last decade there has been a slowdown in this reduction in inequality, if not a step backwards. And in this sense we must give a new impetus, and that is why the Committee on Budgets has made some proposals. We ask, for example, that all chapters of the European budget have clear gender objectives and that the budget allocated to achieve them be specified. That the projects financed by the European Union have gender indicators, both in the selection of projects and in their monitoring and evaluation. The amount allocated from the annual financial framework to achieve gender equality is a first step, but when we look at the latest figures on the cost of inequality it is clear that it must be increased. And finally, we also ask for a true gender budgeting for the next financial programming. A real political will is necessary to fulfill our commitment and build a more equal and just Europe for all.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, I am here on behalf of, I suppose, the ‘bean-counting’ committee but, given what was said in this Chamber in the last month, I have got to say this: less than a generation ago in my country young, unmarried, pregnant women were treated as lesser beings, their babies consigned to institutions run by so-called religious orders where some were starved to death, others were sold to be experimented on by big pharma less than 50 years ago. The young mothers themselves were often consigned to a life of slavery and abuse in the Magdalene laundries. Things have moved on but we still have a long way to go. We do not have to go back decades to find unequal treatment of women. We do not have to go back to Ireland, why we do not even have to go outside this Chamber. Just this month in the mini plenary in Brussels, one of our supposed colleagues made the statement that because women are smaller, weaker, less intelligent they should be paid less than men. I have news for that MEP: there are women in this Chamber who are bigger, stronger and more intelligent than many men. That does not make them superior to any man. It makes them equal to all. I hope we can go some way to changing what we need to change even further and shutting people like that up.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, allow me to comment on the report on equality between women and men for the period 2014-2015. I would first of all like to thank my colleague Urtasun, who gathered a large amount of factual information and pointed out the fundamental trends in this area. The report objectively states that the situation has improved, albeit very small, very slow and insufficient. Of course, the increase in the education of women, which today accounts for 60% at universities, is positive. The number of women in political positions has increased slightly, today it is 29%. Nevertheless, we cannot, of course, be satisfied that the differences persist, especially in wages, 16% to the detriment of women, to the level of pensions, 40% to the detriment of women. There is still a higher proportion of men in the management of companies, up to 71%. And, of course, we continue to face a high level of violence, which is widespread in the EU, with 33% of women experiencing physical violence. However, what hinders the improvement of conditions for a better distribution of caring roles in the family is, above all, that Member States do not allow, for example, to take paternity leave, 1/4 of Member States do not, 8 Member States do not have paid parental leave. It is clear that today women are not discriminated against because they are women, but because they simply have a different position in the community than men, because they have an irreplaceable motherly role. And related to their role is childcare. Today, 97% of women take care of children on parental leave. So this is the main reason for income differences. Unfortunately, I cannot agree with the unilaterally ideological approach of this report, which does not appreciate the work of caring mothers and parents, and evaluates the traditional division of roles in the family unilaterally, only critically, as stereotypes. Therefore, I will also propose some amendments and, if they are not agreed, I will not be able to support this report.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I wanted, of course, to start the speech by thanking the group rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for the work done on these reports. I believe that it is essential that, today, this Parliament is the loudspeaker of those and of those people who are expressing a concern regarding the stagnation and the steps backwards that are being taken on equality in the European Union. Of course we have made progress, of course we are an example regarding our policies in other territories outside the European Union and that one of the fundamental values ​​of the Union is that equality between men and women, equal opportunities and equal rights . But, unfortunately, politics in recent years has caused a serious setback in all policies, both economic and recognition of rights. The austerity policy has been serious with respect to those policies directed to the attention of public services to which, in many cases, women acceded to favor the policies of reconciliation between personal and working life. But, also, rights policies. We have seen clear examples in which different Member States have tried to legislate on our own lives, on our freedom of decision. And I think that makes us see the need to advance in the recognition of our rights, because those who do not recognize the path that remains to be traveled will hardly get down to work in the fight against gender violence, eliminating the wage gap. and, of course, the pension gap, the question also referring to the budget from the gender point of view. And, of course, let's not forget the political representation of women. Because women have to be represented in all those spaces where important decisions are made about our lives: in the field of politics, economics, trade unions.And also in that sense we have a responsibility to move forward.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! Women's rights and equality are issues that should bind us together here in Parliament. Of course, I also regret the words of one of the parliamentarians who pejoratively assessed women and I absolutely do not agree with such statements. However, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the Committee on Women's Affairs is increasingly dealing with ideological issues, and I think this is working against women. In this committee, we should act together on the basis of good practices, because in many Member States there are really very good practices when it comes to women's rights, for example in the area of ​​closing the wage gap. And my homeland, Poland is such a good example of a country where the wage gap is one of the smallest in the European Union. If we manage to maintain the current trend, we will achieve equal wages for women and men in 2021. Let us not ideologize the work of this committee. Let us fight for these wage gaps in all Member States to be as small as possible, for the disproportions in pensions between women and men to be as small as possible. Let us firmly oppose violence against women in every dimension: material, physical and mental. I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that we do not antagonize each other. I address these words especially to the left side of the room: do not exclude the voice of conservatives who believe that the roles of an employee, mother and wife can be beautifully combined. Help women who want to combine these roles, and do not throw leftist ideology into these solutions. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Thank you for accepting the blue card.I wanted to ask, my colleague, your speech was quite stimulating, however, as you assess the situation where there is no such gender pay gap in Poland, this is indeed evidenced by the European rankings, but there are countries such as my own,Unfortunately, in the Czech Republic, where the differences are staggering, it is 22% of the pay gap between men and women.How do you view this situation?I think we should condemn it, in my opinion it is entirely appropriate.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- First of all, thank you for this question.I always accept questions, unlike those colleagues who believe that our questions are not worth accepting.I think that cooperation at ministerial level could be an appropriate platform for exchanging good practices.As far as I know, Minister Rafalska is very open and will be happy to meet the relevant ministers, not only from the Czech Republic, but also from other countries, to show how Poland managed to reduce this pay gap after many years.We support equal opportunities for all, regardless of gender.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Mrs Jourová, congratulations Mr Urtasun and Mrs Moody, for reports that are as timely as they are necessary. Never like now must we remember that equality in Europe remains a pending task for all. The pay gap should embarrass us as Europeans and it is not a myth, it is a fact, because the figures do not lie. The pay gap in Europe is around 20%. In the case of pensions, it is double, 40%. For those who argue that this is a matter of belief, make no mistake: the devil is in the details. It is not that a European when hired is paid less for being a woman, no. I am going to give you an example: in jobs with a different name but comparable in qualifications, those performed by men are better paid. And that is data. A secretary and an administrative officer with the same tasks and the same responsibility and functions charge differently. A supermarket cashier charges less than a restocker. In other words, it involves, among other things, the description and evaluation of the positions. Do you know what one of the antidotes for this is? Transparency, publish, ask companies to publish the lists of positions, their content and their remuneration. There are those who - at the height of hypocrisy - claim that the gap is due to free decisions by women. Well, some say that we are improving, and it is true, but in an outrageously slow way. The European Commission assures us that if we do not go backwards, it will take 70 years for the gender gap to close. 70 years! We cannot afford 70 years of waiting. It has actually taken a little over 70 years for Mr Korwin-Mikke, who is not here today, to become famous thanks to his despicable xenophobic, racist and sexist claims of him in this House. I thank President Tajani for his apologies on behalf of the European Parliament and I hope to hear shortly about the sanction that will be imposed and I trust that it will be the maximum possible. Because, Mr Korwin-Mikke, even if you are not here to listen to this, I also find it difficult to believe that you and I receive the same salary, that European citizens dedicate the same taxes to pay you and me, and that our vote respective value has the same value. But those are the rules of representative democracy, because there is no wage gap between MEPs. Mr Korwin-Mikke charges the same as Mrs Marine Le Pen or Mr Farage or I or any of us here. The gap that we must truly close in Parliament is the one that ignores or ridicules our work, the one that puts a fair mirror between the citizens and their representatives, the one that only shows Europhobic punches, filonazi sexism or morbid appointments. Because achieving true equality between men and women will not be a victory for one over the other, but a shared achievement. Because we all win with a fairer society that does not waste the talent, effort and competition of half the world. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Diane James (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. I was formerly an EFDD Member, I now sit as an independent, but I do take issue with your accusation against Mr Farage. Can I just ask you what you feel about a political party whose membership in terms of women has probably got the highest representation from a particular country and probably represents the best in terms of women’s political future? How does that stand in terms of the accusations you made?

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: "blue card" response.- Regarding what you say, I am very happy that your party has such a high degree of participation, but what your party wants is to destroy the European Union.And what we are talking about, equality in general, but equality between men and women as a fundamental pillar, is the backbone of the European Union.Then I see a contradiction in your terms.I am glad that you are participating actively as women, but it would be better to participate to build and not to destroy.

name: Stefan Eck
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Last week we used International Women's Day to draw attention to the grievances that are still rampant and the current threatening developments in the area of ​​gender equality. During the last plenary session in Brussels, a colleague had to painfully remind us that even in the European Parliament there were medieval and extremely worrying statements made against women. Fortunately, this act of discrimination has been duly reprimanded by you. Today I would like to address another major problem area: We are observing an increasing feminization of poverty in the EU. It is triggered by the austerity measures imposed in the wake of the austerity policy, particularly in public services and the health system. The austerity policy is leading to a massive wave of privatization, which affects the quality of care and the responsibility for caring for small children and old people in our society is once again incumbent on the families and therefore mostly has to be assumed by women. For this reason, I would like to expressly thank the rapporteur, Mr Urtasun, for his report, because he identifies this development and its connections and calls on the Member States to support horizontal solutions and to work consistently against current developments.

name: Monika Vana
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! I would like to thank the rapporteur, Clare Moody, for the extremely good cooperation on her report on gender equality in the EU funds. As has been said repeatedly, this report comes at exactly the right time, also in the context of International Women's Day. We Greens warmly welcome this report because it speaks a clear language and because it reveals major grievances, especially grievances in the area of ​​inadequate implementation of gender mainstreaming. We all know that gender mainstreaming is actually an obligation of the European Union. We are here, so we have a certain responsibility to actually implement it. But this is also not the case in the EU funds and EU programs in particular, and this is what this report shows. We have a lot of catching up to do here, and of course we are calling for gender mainstreaming to be implemented in all EU programs and all EU funds. An essential key instrument of gender mainstreaming is gender budgeting - I think that has already been mentioned by one or the other today - where we think that the European Commission, in particular, is lagging far behind its implementation possibilities although for years there have been repeated calls from this House, and also from the Women's Committee and other committees, to apply gender budgeting not just in the areas where it is easiest or most obvious, but really in all programs. In conclusion, I would like to once again point out the importance of the European Structural Funds for overcoming the crisis and achieving gender equality goals and the importance of public investment in social infrastructure in order to cope with the gender-specific effects of the crisis and austerity policy.

name: Daniela Aiuto
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime I wanted to congratulate the rapporteurs on the excellent work they have done, however, if you allow me, tonight I would like to take advantage of this debate to address a few words to all those who think like ours, now sadly famous , colleague from Poland. I know that they are not in here and I hope they are very little outside too. Here, I would like to say to these people, do you know who discovered the Higgs boson in 2012, the so-called God particle? She was a woman, an Italian physicist: her name is Fabiola Gianotti. And do you know who is the greatest stem cell researcher in the world? It is the Italian researcher Elena Cattaneo. I come from the Abruzzo region, home to the Gran Sasso laboratories of the National Institute of Nuclear Physics. And do you know who runs these world famous workshops? Physics Lucia Votano. My dear colleagues, we women demonstrate our worth, our skills and our competence more and more every day and therefore we demand equal remuneration, both during our working life and in retirement. And anyone who thinks that women are inferior in anything to men is right in only one respect: because no woman, unlike a man, would ever go down this very low level of human evolution with our colleague's claims.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the reports debated this evening reveal the objective set by the FEMM committee. Double objective: first, to deconstruct what has been established, even if, for that, we must deny even the natural law; secondly, to rebuild ideology with great blows, all this while giving as a guarantee the defense of noble ideals. The titles evoke great causes, the content more resembles a series of communitarian demands. The report by MP Kozłowska-Rajewicz takes stock of equality between men and women in access to goods and services. Good concrete proposals are made in favor of working women and mothers, on the creation of reception infrastructures for their children or the social and legal protection of the latter. But, quickly, the ideology emerges: we no longer speak of equality between men and women, but of the fight against discrimination based on sexual practice, gender reassignment or gender. MP Moody's report criticizes the use of EU funds on gender equality. While I share his criticism of the lack of control, I cannot help but note the many communitarian paragraphs. You want to strengthen the “Asylum, migration and integration” fund by creating specific funding to ensure the safety of migrants and refugees. Nice gesture, if it was not done to the detriment of all citizens of the European Union! Indeed, AMIF represents 510 million euros, just for the situation in Greece, to finance the relocation of migrants who entered illegally. 500 euros per head, the gift is indeed beautiful, but salty for the European taxpayer. You don't stop there. You are asking for the payment of 18 million euros to the Daphne program, which aims to fight gender discrimination. Here we are again. It is nevertheless symptomatic: the FEMM commission cannot help but refer to gender, the product of an ideology which aims to make believe that the individual is no longer a boy or a girl at birth, by virtue of of his sex, but a being brought to define himself, as he sees fit, according to his desires and his sexual practices. Yes, men and women are equal before the law, and no, their sexual practices have nothing to do with this sacred equality. In the report by Deputy Urtasun, you are heading in the same direction. Discrimination against LGBTI people, categorized by you, would be the consequence of their sexual practices. You call for penalizing so-called homophobic attitudes, which would give an LGBT man or woman a special right by virtue of their sexual practice. For the commission, which claims to be the champion of equality between men and women, it is funny. Under the pretext of fighting against inequalities, your ideological blindness leads you to categorize people according to their situation and to pit them against other categories: women against men, migrants against Europeans, LGBTI against heterosexuals, And the list is long. Finally, you attack conscientious objection, and this is very serious. Protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the European Convention on Human Rights and national legislation, it guarantees freedom of thought, conscience and religion in any society. Calling it into question amounts to removing a right which allows many people to work in conscience and in freedom.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, equal treatment in the eyes of the law is a fundamental principle in a liberal democracy. No one should be discriminated against for their gender, their age, their race, their sexual preference or even their physical ability. But neither should people face positive discrimination and be placed ahead of others to satisfy quotas. This is just as unjust as other forms of discrimination. The United Kingdom has led the way in a whole series of areas. It gave women the right to vote in 1928 and via other acts of parliament it has guaranteed rights to equal pay, equal access to jobs for genders and for all sorts of cultural and societal reasons. We were even one of the first countries to elect a female Prime Minister, and we have also now got a second one. The United Kingdom has got a long history of enshrining equality in law. Nevertheless, there is work in progress. We recognise that. We understand, we appreciate that in some areas Scandinavian Member States are ahead of us, and yet in many areas the United Kingdom stands heads and shoulders above other Member States. Simply put, the United Kingdom expects and requires that women, and other issues relating to this topic, around the world should receive equal treatment and equal opportunities and that discrimination should be made an element of the past. These are challenges best delivered and best addressed by national, sovereign parliaments. If we take away that role, if we take away that control, all you do is sow the seeds of discord, disillusionment and division.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, we meet regularly in this hemicycle around March 8 to take stock, all of us together. This evening, we are debating three reports which were discussed and then voted on in the Committee on Women's Rights. I will start my remarks with a few words on the report by our colleague Moody, words which I will say in replacement of our colleague, Barbara Matera, who was the shadow rapporteur of the EPP Group on this report, and who cannot be with us this evening, because of the birth of her child. The Moody report is devoted to the need to integrate the gender dimension into the European Union budget as a horizontal policy objective. Certain European programs, foremost among them the "Rights, equality and citizenship" program, as well as the Horizon 2020 program, contain specific actions in favor of equality between men and women. The first program is absolutely essential for funding actions to combat violence against women; the second, Horizon 2020, offers opportunities to develop funding actions to promote female entrepreneurship: two major causes that are among the key priorities of the PPE group. In the work on the Moody report, we wanted, as a group, to underline the major role played by the European Social Fund in the financing of projects to fight against discrimination against women, in the financing of projects promoting the 'Men and women equality. We also wanted to draw attention to the need to focus, perhaps more, the various European funds dedicated to actions in favor of equality between men and women, on projects which are truly concrete, for which studies impact and feedback made it possible to see that there was a real effectiveness and real positive feedback.Once again, it is important that, indeed, European funds take this priority action very seriously, but at the same time we must know how to keep reason and be thrifty when it comes to the management of European taxpayers' money.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D).
text: - Thank you, p. Mr President, Commissioner, it is good to see you here. First of all, I would like to thank all three rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for their great work and reports, but despite the various pieces of legislation, recommendations and strategies in the field of gender equality, the reality is that we are only halfway to achieving gender equality. the progress that is being made is simply insufficient. There is still no progress in reducing the gender pay gap. Some countries may be performing better, say, but according to the latest Eurostat data, in some Member States this gap has even widened over the last five years, which of course affects both lower women's pensions and higher female poverty. . It must also be acknowledged that it is more difficult for women to reconcile work and family responsibilities. The worries of childcare, upbringing, and nursing of family members usually lie on their shoulders. As a result, their professional careers and social security are affected, and, Commissioner, we look forward to the package on reconciling work and family life promised by the Commission at the end of April and to the proposal for four directives. I would like to draw one more thing and simply call on the Member States to take concrete measures to combat violence against women. Indeed, it is very important that the Member States ratify the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women without delay, as so far only half of the countries of the European Union have taken such a decision. Finally, gender mainstreaming is essential and requires some funding in addition to political will and awareness. So let’s unite and act together.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, over the last week or so, what with International Women’s Day and the rather odious comments from a rather odious colleague, the issue of gender equality has been very prominent. On the one hand, this is incredibly encouraging as it demonstrates the broad recognition that inequality is unacceptable in this day and age. But on the other hand, it is also a little bit sad, as despite the overwhelming consensus that there is absolutely no reason why women should be treated differently or be more restricted in their life choices than men, women are still battling to put an end to unjustifiable forms of gender discrimination. This I find quite exasperating. Of course, putting an end to gender inequality is not easy. It is a sad truth that such inequality is so deeply embedded in our society that it has become a form of socialisation that many are simply unaware of. Choices made in education and decisions taken with regard to work-life balance are all, to an extent, influenced by some form of gender stereotyping which can lock women into situations or careers where they are at an unfair disadvantage to men. From society, women and girls need positive role models to help them see beyond such entrenched stereotypes. From Member State governments, they need a level playing field that allows them the chance to pursue careers and shine, based on merit alone. The increased willingness and growing urgency of action opens the door for change. However, unless this willingness translates into meaningful action there is absolutely no guarantee that gender inequality will be fully resolved. It is Member State governments that will make this happen most quickly and most appropriately. It is therefore vital that we as policymakers use this momentum to pin gender equality at the top of all our governments’ to-do lists.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I am very pleased that we are having this joint debate today on equality between men and women. As is well known, International Women's Day was only celebrated last week, on March 8th. It is therefore all the more important to keep this topic on the agenda, because we are still far from achieving equality between men and women and we must all the more continue our efforts to achieve the ambitious goals that we are put us all at EU level. Tomorrow we will be voting on three important reports. Each one is geared towards empowering women and reducing gender discrimination in various areas. An important point in all of these matters is how we as politicians take gender mainstreaming into account in our daily work. Because when it comes to formulating political goals and implementing them in practice, the differences between men and women are still all too visible. We must therefore take greater account of the different difficulties women and men face in all areas of life - in this context, above all, the reality that women face. European equality laws are not always uniform enough and implementation needs to be improved. The independence and resources of European gender equality agencies also need to be strengthened. I am therefore looking forward to continuing to work with my colleagues in Parliament, the Commission and the Council to further reduce these differences between women and men. Because we often say that it takes courage to put your convictions into words and to make them known. But it is much more important to stand by these convictions. In this sense we have to use the terms equality, Treat feminism and gender equality not only as eloquent pieces of jewelry, but as essential components of our everyday life on a political as well as any other social level.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the discrimination that affects women in accessing goods and services is increasing, with regard to their ability to acquire and choose, an inseparable reality of discrimination in access to quality employment and decent salaries and pensions. Discriminatory practices continue in services offered by the insurance and banking sector, with values ​​and rates differentiated by sex, namely by including weighting factors associated with pregnancy, maternity planning and maternity itself, factors also considered in access to leasing and acquiring housing or obtaining loans. Also in the access to medical goods and services, situations of discrimination and differentiation continue to occur - practices that deserve vigorous repudiation and that must be eliminated; practices that highlight, as evident, the need to reinforce access to free and quality public services, namely in sectors such as health or maternity and child care support services. But it is necessary to remember that inequalities between men and women have deepened in the most elementary levels of life, in an unprecedented civilizational setback, and that this reality cannot be disconnected either from the policies of exploitation and profit, or from the policies of the Union European Union, namely austerity and impoverishment policies that promote low wages, job insecurity and job deregulation and working hours.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, may I thank all the rapporteurs for the good work they have done. Europe needs gender equality not only for the sake of social justice, freedom and dignity for all human beings but also to foster economic development, prosperity and wellbeing across the Union. We cannot wait another 70 years, as the Commission estimates, to achieve full gender equality. We need to speed up the rate of change now, and for this we need specific policy initiatives and political commitment from every single European government – also, of course, the European Commission. Advancing legislation in the following areas seems to me essential: fostering equal sharing of care responsibilities and domestic work between men and women; suppressing the gender pay gap under the principle of equal pay for work of equal value; better regulation of parental leave and maternity leave; improving access for women to decision-making positions; and, finally, fighting gender-based violence.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in the report regarding EU funds for gender equality there is a call for more EU funding. Whilst I fully support tackling violence against women and discrimination, and agree that Member States should do more, an increase in the EU budget is utterly against UKIP principles. Taxpayers’ money should not be spent by unaccountable EU bureaucrats. Another report reviewing equal treatment in the access to, and supply of, goods and services welcomes the ECJ Test Achats ruling. This removed Article 5(2), which meant that insurance premiums could not be calculated differently between men and women. I find it extremely hypocritical that the EU wants gender quotas in boardrooms, but that you are more than happy to take away one of the few advantages that women could have had and that was justifiable so long as it was proven by credible data. What was once a transparent way of calculating premiums has now led to insurance companies finding hidden alternatives, for example, basing premiums on employment sectors which have a higher percentage of males and females. The final report on gender equality calls for gender quotas on boards of listed companies and encourages Member States to dissolve companies that do not tick those boxes. It goes on to call for gender quotas for elections and in the explanatory statement it talks about the division of household responsibilities. How couples choose to divide household chores between them in the privacy of their own home is not an area for the EU to dictate. I would just like to remind everyone that the United Kingdom passed the Equal Pay Act in 1970, pre-dating our entry into the European Union in 1973. The UK does not need to rely on the EU for women’s rights. We will continue to fight for equal treatment long after we have gone.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). - Mr President, all members of a society must have equal obligations and rights, whether men or women. Such distinctions are incompatible with the values ​​and principles on which Western culture is built. Women have an additional very important role, the upbringing of children, and they are the guarantee for the healthy development of our society. This is exactly the role we must protect. Work should not be an obstacle for women when they want to have children. The state must support and protect them, as this would be a solution to the chronic problem of low birth rate. Even greater leave must be introduced for new mothers. National health systems must support women throughout pregnancy and beyond, ensuring immediate and free access to health services. But we do not agree with the policies of positive discrimination, as they introduce distortions that create more problems than they would like to solve. During the crisis, unemployment rates rose to unbearable levels for both men and women. Employment has not yet recovered from pre-crisis rates. As a result, the number of families financially dependent on women's work is constantly increasing. We are opposed to any discrimination, positive or negative, between men and women. We seek full equality of opportunity, the only real equality that ensures the smooth functioning of society. But can we ensure that these principles and our values ​​are also embraced by those who come to Europe uninvited from countries where women are considered inferior and simply an object?

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I care very much about equality between women and men, and I am therefore sorry that this report is further proof that a large number of colleagues in this House see the European Treaties as a bowl with canapés. They choose only what they like. And like people who never reach for a salmon sandwich, our avid progressives have an allergic reaction to the principle of subsidiarity. Article 168 (7) of the Treaty states that the Union's action shall respect the responsibilities of the Member States for the definition of their health policy and for the organization and delivery of health services and medical care. Nevertheless, the report presented in paragraph 46 calls on all Member States to guarantee women's easy access to a wide range of sexual and reproductive health services, including contraception and abortion. Paragraph 47 calls on EU countries to ensure that conscientious objection clauses do not prevent patients from accessing legal medical care. Ladies and gentlemen, let me repeat: the responsibility for defining health policy, organizing and delivering health services and healthcare lies with the Member States, not the European Union. And it is not up to the European Parliament, but national parliaments, to legislate in the Member States in this area. Your efforts at all costs to assert your worldview, while ignoring treaties and laws, are one of the reasons for people's growing dissatisfaction with the way European integration is based. You, too, bear some of the responsibility for the rise of Euroscepticism, which you are so fond of talking about.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the reports we are discussing today are the result of intense work, important work and for this I thank all the rapporteurs very much; I would like in particular to thank my colleague Urtasun, with whom I was able to work more closely, as I was the shadow rapporteur for his report. The statistics that the Commission has presented to us for the two-year period 14-15 are not, colleagues, too encouraging. The data is improving, of course, but it is improving too slowly and, after all, it is not just statistics that are needed to tell us how things change so slowly; we don't need statistics to tell the hard work that is still made to be a woman. This is what our daily life tells us, the daily life of our friends, our sisters, our fellow citizens and the women we meet every day on our path. Our life here also tells us about it, when we hear violent words, unacceptable words, shameful words, which we heard some time ago. And then we are aware, today more than ever, that the work we have to do, that the road that leads to full equality is still a long way, it is still a tortuous road; there are many things to do and we find many of the things to do in these reports, which we hope will really serve as a stimulus to the Member States to do things, to guarantee those rights that are still shamefully denied to many women. I am thinking, for example, of the rights to sexual and reproductive health which are still denied today, colleagues. And then the things we have said are all important things, you have said so many significant things. But I want to remember the last, the last important thing: the achievement of absolute equality between men and women cannot be separated from a real and authentic fight against gender violence, which still seems to be today a virus that takes on new forms; I think about violence on social networks and bullying.In short, there is still a lot of work to be done, but we are here, colleagues, and we are ready to do it.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: - Mr President, when we talk about equality between men and women, I cannot fail to mention one very important issue, namely the differences between men and women in the payment of pensions.
