This difference, which in some countries is as high as 40 percent, is due not only to lower female employment, but also to their lower valuation and periods of taking care of other family members. I know that, in this context, several Members are reluctant to look at non-traditional, flexible working hours. Personally, however, I do not agree with this view. I think that flexible working, for example in the form of part-time work, can be very helpful, for example, for parents of younger children who want to better organize their own work-life balance. I will be happy if we succeed in promoting that we can make better use of the opportunities offered by flexibility in organizing work in our countries, and at the same time that we do not deprive women of retirement age. I think that the European Parliament, the European Commission, is a very good forum for us to learn more about good practice in this area.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in the face of machismo and patriarchy we need this Parliament, the Commission and the Member States to truly believe in gender equality, because it is a political principle to advance towards democracy, social justice and rights humans. In short: towards a just society. We continue, Commissioner, without an equality strategy, despite the fact that the pension gap - as has already been said here - is around 40% and the average wage gap is 16%. Let's also talk about gender violence, because in Europe one in three women has suffered physical or sexual violence at some time. In Spain, in the little that we have done this year 2017, there are already twenty women murdered. And let us also defend our right to terminate pregnancy freely in the face of conservative attacks. Laws, without a budget or with a minimum budget, as happens in my country with the Dependency Law or the Comprehensive Law against gender violence, are just wet paper and a toast to the sun. Please, Commissioner, do not take this issue as a politically correct speech, but as something strictly necessary for a just society.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, thanks to comrade Ernest Urtasun for his great work.This report shows that Europe is falling halfway to achieving gender equality, and the really important thing here is to ask ourselves what are we doing while more than half of women are sexually harassed, what are we doing while women earn less than women?men for the same job, what are we doing while excluding women from management positions in companies and institutions.And, more importantly, what are we going to do.Will governments continue to cut equally?Will they continue to block the Directives on maternity and paternity, and on quotas on company boards of directors?The European Commission must now take up these Directives, it must integrate the gender perspective globally in all its policies and it must have a gender equality strategy.Less talking and more acting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: - Mister President! So today we are talking about three templates for re-educating people on the basis of gender ideology. In the name of gender and anti-discrimination, marriage between men and women is discriminated against. The last Noichl report spoke of the health risks posed by marriage. And now you are amazed at the growing resistance to this gender nonsense and you want to analyze it. The analysis is simple: the vast majority of people are simply men and women. They marry or not. They become fathers and mothers, and they don't want the whole of society to be turned upside down because of a few exceptions and small minorities, and that too for a lot of money. People have very real problems: work, pensions, health, safety - public toilets for the third gender and gender-sensitive nature parks are not among them. That is why we, as a party, have only one word in our program on the subject: not a cent for this nonsense.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, these three reports come together in a clear statement. Of course, a lot of progress has been made, but we still have a long way to go to achieve fair equality between women and men. Among the many debates that these reports give rise to, some themes are dear to me. Among these, the right to abortion and access to reproductive rights. Of course, I cannot speak of these rights without thinking of Simone Veil, a woman who has so marked our continent and this hemicycle over which she so brilliantly chaired. I understand that in the name of the principle of subsidiarity or out of religious conscience, some national delegations have different positions. However, as long as the right to abortion and access to reproductive rights are discussed in this Chamber, I will proudly vote in favor. For me, this is a fundamental right which, in the face of the radicalization of certain political currents, today needs all the more to be claimed and protected. It’s a matter of common sense. The place of women in the economy and in business is also one of the points on which France can be proud of having made progress. Thus, the Copé-Zimmerman law, since 2011, institutes the obligation of a balanced representation of women and men on the boards of directors and supervisory of companies. We are pleased that the texts of the European Parliament and of the Commission now recommend this. Thank you, Commissioner, for continuing to work so that a directive can finally be issued in this direction. Even if they are not perfect, and because I believe that women’s rights should not be limited to the establishment of a communication day, I will therefore vote in favor of these three reports.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I would like to thank the rapporteur, Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz, for the good cooperation on her report on equal access to goods and services, as she, like me, aims to achieve equality for all people in Europe. The implementation of the principle of equal treatment is an indicator of the level of development of democracy. It is therefore particularly regrettable that in many cases discrimination still determines people's everyday lives. Because who doesn't know that: the disposable razor for women costs a lot more than the same product that is available for men. The short haircut for a woman is quite a bit more expensive than the same haircut for a man and so on and so forth. We can all cite countless examples from our everyday lives. This is our reality. It has been ten years since the directive on equal treatment for men and women in access to goods and services had to be implemented. Much has happened. But of course there are still numerous pitfalls that everyday life offers, and in many cases these differences are practically burned into our society and perceived as so normal that you often no longer notice them. In public spaces, it is often mothers and breastfeeding women who struggle with discrimination. You cannot use many services and are sometimes simply left standing at the airport, for example, despite a valid ticket. Women are also affected by higher costs and different pricing for insurance and credit products. The prices of other goods and services are also often set on a gender-specific basis, and there are still these explicit exceptions in the area of ​​media, advertising and education. Changing that would of course be very desirable. With We are making small but steady steps here in the European Parliament.The Commission is now called upon to carry out a study in the field of advertising.I ask you to support at least that.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I would like to express my outrage at some passages in this Urtasun report. For example, it states that the conscientious objection clause is overused. What does that mean, please? This prevents women from accessing basic health care. Secondly, let me make it clear that this report obscures vague terminology. Why does the term basic health care also include abortion, please? I fundamentally disagree with the classification of abortions being classified as basic health care, because we are confusing the public. Next, do we really want to deny the doctor the right to a reservation here? Don't be angry, what does that mean? I believe that doctors and staff should have legal support in the conscience of abortion when it comes to performing an abortion. Next, there are a few points where there are movements in society and in politics that run counter to the rights of women and others, such as the LGBT, and emphasize traditional roles. So why not, please? There are millions of people who think this is right. Because traditional roles do not mean that we have to run away from children and not take care of our families. Yes, there are millions of people who want to do this. So you need to respect that.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work on these reports. I believe that an honest approach to advocating for gender equality should put people and care at the center of politics, in the same way that they are at the center of life. We have to understand that the unequal participation of women in the labor market and the inequality between men and women also have to do with the unequal distribution of care tasks. Therefore, the public authorities must assume their responsibility by promoting a new social and public system of care that allows all people to care, that allows all people to be cared for and that values ​​the potential of care as a mechanism to create employment, to generate social and economic development, to promote social justice. We must defend a strategy at the level of the Union to introduce the gender approach in all actions, programs and public policies for the period 2016-2020, and that involves budgeting with a gender perspective and shielding budgets for gender policies , something that would allow us to combat sexist violence in a coordinated manner throughout the Union, something that we have not been doing so far.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President! Thanks to Mr Ernest Urtasun, our rapporteur. Today we are talking about equality between women and men. I would then like to highlight a special aspect of it, namely mental illness. As a green member, I really see that well-being and balance in life are linked to a sustainable society. Mental illness is a major growing problem, especially among young people, and men and women are affected differently by inequality. We need to stop hatred and threats online. Women's double work makes them extra vulnerable to mental illness. We need to better equip our young boys, as loneliness, crime and addiction are grossly overrepresented among men. Combating mental illness at the gate is about a sustainable society - a society where everyone has room to grow based on their special conditions. We must put people at the center in a completely new way. It is about tackling poverty and poor conditions in the labor market, but also about fighting violence and discrimination. I want to see large investments in the female-dominated sector and reduced working hours. Of course, I want all parents in my Europe to have the right to parental leave. I want special efforts to strengthen young boys and men to break destructive male norms. In addition, I want investments in strengthening young girls' self-confidence and opportunities. Let feminism take its place!

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Dear President, if equality between men and women is one of the fundamental values ​​of the European Union, and this has been a fact since the Rome Agreements of 1957, when the principle of equal pay for equal work became part of the Treaty of Rome, then it is really strange that even today on average, women earn about 16% less per hour than men. There are several reasons for this, we heard it here tonight from our commissioner Jurova, but also from other colleagues. I will once again list just a few to perhaps reflect on: discrimination in the workplace that can be both direct and indirect and that is prohibited; the fact that different jobs and different sectors in which women work are paid less than those in which men dominate; repeatedly mentioned by the fact that workplace practices and the pay system are such that women do not have the same access to training, employee rewards and funds. In addition, the jobs that women do and women's skills are underestimated and are less valued because they are seen as an expression of innate female characteristics rather than acquired skills and competencies. We also know that there is a shortage of women in managerial positions, that there are not enough of them in politics and the economy, and that only one third of women are scientists, engineers in the European Union. Gender roles and traditions influence career choices and educational pathways. And another reason, or cause, is the reconciliation of work and family obligations. This has been discussed several times. Women work shorter and often full-time jobs, and the pay gap increases even more when women become mothers. What I would like to appeal to once again today is that we respect the fundamental value of the European Union, and that is equality between men and women, that we finally implement the fifteen directives we have in this area, and I believe we will succeed soon. , but we must be in solidarity and work together. (The speaker agreed to answer a question posed by raising a blue card (Article 162. paragraph 8 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Question by raising a blue card - Dear colleague, I wonder if you might know why Croatia has not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention?Namely, the party you come from has been in power for more than a year, the current Prime Minister said in November last year that ratification would be launched, however, he encountered great resistance in his own party.Can you explain to me a little bit what is actually going on and why it wasn’t made?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- First of all, we could have this debate in Croatia, we did not have to come to Brussels to lead this debate.In any case, we are in favor of ratifying the Istanbul Convention.A working group is currently being set up at the level of the Ministry of the Family and Demographic Reconstruction and I believe that the Istanbul Convention will be ratified soon after the deliberations because what we are really fighting against is violence against women.I am sorry that the previous government, which was four years old, did not ratify the Istanbul Convention, and the excuse was that it was a big expense.So, I believe that we will be able to solve the violence against women even by ratifying the Istanbul Convention.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, access to goods and services and the provision of goods and services are two areas where gender equality has never really been taken into account. These are sectors that are increasingly dominated by men. This is the reason why it is necessary to take strong positions in this regard. While the proposed directive offers solid tools to ensure the principle of equality between men and women, achieving the full potential of the directive depends on raising awareness among service providers and users, as well as on coherent integration the dimension of gender equality in the sectors concerned by this provision. On the issue of Union funds for gender equality, I would like to stress that, even if several economic support programs relating to gender equality exist, very few of these programs define clear objectives, specific, effective implementation or systematic monitoring. As for the annual report on gender equality, I would like to point out that, in general, all of us Europeans, human rights defenders, must mobilize in order to defend equal rights between women and men. In the professional sector, I see that the differences are still numerous. To the Council, I would remind you that it is thanks to him - or because of him - that European maternity leave is forgotten. What about the 28 Member States who have once again decided to postpone the discussion on the issue of the representation of women on company boards? From the Commission, I will ask for clear measures to fight more effectively against sexual harassment in the workplace. Women are still discriminated against in the world of employment, especially when they are lesbian, bisexual or transgender. For these latest, did you know that, for example, over 30% of transgender job applications experienced severe discrimination in their searches?Behind these statistics, people suffer daily from the violation of their rights.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr Chairman!Mr.In this interesting voice, you highlighted various types of discrimination, but don't you think that the worst possible discrimination is the one that we are not talking about, because silence about discrimination is the worst structural violence.I am talking about complete silence about women who voluntarily choose to work at home to look after children, for example.We know that at the moment families bringing up children are often the most economically weakest social groups.Why are we not talking about those women who voluntarily quit their jobs and deserve our respect?

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: answer "blue card". - There are multiple forms of discrimination, but it is clear that we must focus on access to professions, access to training, access to studies. We have a lot of respect for the women who make the choice to stay at home, to have the children, to raise them, it is their choice, there is no problem. But what is abominable in our society is that 60% of people who succeed in higher education are women and the higher you move up the corporate hierarchy - whether in the public sector or in the private sector - the more they disappear depending on the glass ceiling. The discrimination in relation to the difference in pay is also shocking and it is therefore quite normal that we try to redress these injustices, which have too often been admitted. Today, we have to fight and ensure that progress - because there is progress - goes much faster.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Precisely because the European Union aspires to the role of a world leader in terms of women's rights, as part of the exercise of this right, we should pay attention to the psychophysical differences between men and women and help women legally reconcile their vocation of wife and mother with professional work or scientific ambitions, thanks to counting the period of maternity and parental leave to working time and paying childcare equivalents, which would guarantee a similar pension amount for women and men, instead of sending women to work in favor of paternity leave, because even the most committed father or well-paid nanny, nursery or kindergarten will not replace a child loving mother. According to a Swedish study several years ago, fathers on parental leave preferred to hunt moose or watch TV and read newspapers than look after their children. Forced equality, against the natural rights of women, leads to the pathology of the family, violence to which we are intensely opposed.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). - Mr President, I think it is time for all of us here in the European Parliament to say: end to declarations, end to words. It is time to take action. In fact, taking advantage of the presence of the Commissioner, to say that the European Commission has the greatest responsibility for the issue of gender equality. The European Union, whose history, culture, principles, values, path, are in favor of equality, equality, can not find itself through its reports that it was not possible to bridge the gap wages and pensions, the gap in the treatment of men and women. I believe that by definition the European Union is opposed to gender discrimination. By definition, the European Union must safeguard this gender equality, and I believe that it is up to the European Union not to have to talk every year and dedicate days, in fact, to affirm the obvious: that it is our duty to defend gender equality. of both sexes. I believe that there is a huge responsibility but also a challenge, and we must not in any case bypass and ignore what is happening in practice. The budget of the European Union had to essentially integrate the gender dimension through integration into the programs, in the various funds. The European Union could step up this effort in practice. I express my respect, my appreciation and my admiration to every woman, working woman, mother woman, woman fighter, but at the same time I owe from this step to express my admiration, pride and appreciation for the woman of my country , of the Cypriot woman, who has been a refugee for 43 years, but is struggling, at the same time she is a worker and gives the fight, so that she can return to her home, so that she can stop being a trapped woman in Cyprus, to stop is a refugee woman, to stop virtually this torment that exists through the Turkish invasion and occupation, through the tragedy of 1974.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, back in March last year, the European Commission launched the process of ratification of the Istanbul Convention, but despite this, the Council is hampering the progress of the process. In the European Union, seven women die from the effects of violence every day. An interesting survey was conducted in Croatia, which showed that almost half of students believe that a woman can be hit if she shows more attention to friends than to her partner, if she is not obedient or if she does not take care of her partner as she should. Truly scary. We have a 100 percent increase in crimes related to domestic violence. We can't wait a day. I submitted amendments on sexual and reproductive health to the report on equality between men and women. On the one hand, we do not educate young people about sex education, and on the other hand, we prohibit abortion. In Poland, which has one of the most restrictive abortion laws, 80 to 120 thousand abortions are performed annually. With the ban on abortion, that practice does not stop, but becomes the privilege of the rich who can afford to go to another country and do so. Women should be given access to the labor market, health education, protection from sexual and other forms of violence, and access to contraception, rather than talking about what to do with their bodies. I am proud that the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia has decided how to enable abortion. I believe that it is necessary to regulate the appeal of conscience so that each hospital has a minimum number of doctors who can perform this procedure.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: - I advocate an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for everyone. This applies not only to all genders, especially women and girls, but also to people with disabilities and other minority groups. A structural approach to gender inequality is needed. Mandatory quotas or more funding without concrete measures are no guarantee for more equality in the labor market or in the public sphere. People should receive equal pay for equal work. We can only close the gender pay gap with greater transparency and a thorough evaluation of the gender pay gap. It is unacceptable that we see little progress in the fight against violence against women and gender-based violence. Violence against women, as well as against men and children, is a very gross violation of fundamental rights. I therefore call for support for the Istanbul Convention to eradicate this extreme form of discrimination.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the subject I am now bringing to your attention is an elementary thing for the balance between women and men, especially in the context of labor relations. No matter what we are discussing here, in Strasbourg or in Brussels, there are certain tragic realities that are at the heart of the whole debate. If we miss the solutions that can provide us with a solid foundation, all our ambition for progress in relationships and gender balance will be in vain. This is not the first time that the press has reported situations in which women who have gone to work in another Member State, sometimes without an employment contract, are subjected to unimaginable and unacceptable abuses for our society and values. The most recent case is that reported by the British publication The Observer about thousands of women in Romania who work in southern Italy in inhumane conditions. These women, in cases documented by experts, are victims of beatings, exploitation or blackmail, some being forced to have sex with their employers. That is why I said at the beginning that we must not miss the solutions to the basic problems. Although unimaginable for many of us, up to equal pay or representation at work, some women are faced with such a reality. Nowhere in the world can women be treated like this, and yet these things happen every day in the European Union. This parliament must now take a stand and call on each and every one of you, and especially on your colleagues in Italy, to support any action that will restore not only the dignity but also the freedom of these women. We must act urgently against the real black labor market in the European Union, which is causing so much controversy, trouble and suffering.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, gender equality remains the greatest challenge of our time. The gender gap has narrowed significantly in recent years, but progress varies from one Member State to another, and inequalities persist in various areas. An extremely large number of women continue to be discriminated against, deprived of equal opportunities in education and the labor market, and excluded from leadership and decision-making positions. According to Eurostat, the current average number of women on the boards of the largest listed companies in Europe is just 23.9%. In addition, despite the fact that 60% of university graduates are women, these women still receive 16% lower pay per hour than men. In addition, the crisis and the memoranda have mainly harmed women. Finally, another major challenge for the Union remains the fight against violence against women. It is estimated that one in three women in the European Union has experienced physical or sexual violence since the age of 15. Mr President, immediate action is needed.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, on the issue, I would like to begin by saying that the Polish colleague, who has already been mentioned, did not come here, that we were spared some of his allusions and nonsense, which we unfortunately had to hear at the last meeting of the women's parties. In this sense, I would, of course, also appreciate women's rights and their role. I also want to support the EU's efforts to achieve equality, because the EU has undoubtedly made unprecedented progress in this field over many decades. We can no longer talk about direct discrimination, but rather we are talking about that indirect discrimination. And of course there is still something to do, it is evident from various statistics. I do not want to deal only with the domestic issue, however, I have already mentioned here that in the Czech Republic, the wages received by women are significantly lower by 22%. I think it would be necessary to do something about it in our backyard. I do not think that anyone can agree with this, although there are a number of ideologically colored statements in that report. I would like to support her.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Clare Moody, Ernest Urtasun and the other colleagues, both men and women, who are here working together to progress women’s rights and gender equality, not just in Europe but globally. I thought we had won this battle – that I and my feminist brothers and sisters could take a rest from our worker as activists. But we are living through a watershed moment in the history in the struggle for women’s rights. Sadly, anti-gender, misogynists, conservative and nationalist parties are trying to roll back the achievements of generations of feminists and take away our hard-won rights. Women’s rights are human rights. We must therefore use this as a rallying cry to mobilise a new generation of feminists to stand up for what is right, and I mean old feminists and young feminists, women feminists and men feminists. Together with all those fighting for equality and social justice, we bring together a powerful intersectional movement against sexism, homophobia, xenophobia, racism and nationalism, and we can build a more tolerant and a more compassionate world.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Dear President, we have before us another report that encourages national governments and the European Commission to social engineering and openly calls on member states whose citizens mostly disagree with left-wing ideas. I do not know where this right came from, because most of the proposals made in the report are outside its competence. The report implies that the necessary cuts in public spending are some kind of conscious blow to women's rights and, along the way, asks the legislature to interfere in family relations by regulating the distribution of household chores. Soon, it seems, a woman and a man will have to seek permission from the state to run their household, and I would not be surprised if such a zealous legislator prescribes some special record of working hours under the family roof. The administration needs to control everything, everything needs to be tampered with, and only for abortion, according to the report's recommendation, we need to have "easy access". As if it is not about a new human life and as if a woman does not need help and support even in those moments. Scary.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Urtasun and my colleague Moody on their commitment to recognizing the problems of women and to encouraging not only the European Parliament but also the Member States to empower them economically and politically. Economic empowerment has often been mentioned today in speeches, about how much women are underpaid compared to men. However, we have forgotten the fact that one day these women will also retire and that this underpayment will cause them to have a 40% lower pension than men and will enter the category of those citizens who will be poor, those who will not be able to provide yourself with energy, which will not be able to provide food. Unfortunately, the European Union is only at 50%, according to statistics, only 50% of member states have ratified the Istanbul Convention. If we could ratify the Paris Agreement in six months, why were we still not able to ratify the Istanbul Convention when the European Commission proposed it a year ago?

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - President! In Romania, a woman is beaten every 30 seconds and more than 200 women become victims of domestic violence every year. Despite Romania's ratification of the Istanbul Convention last year, a number of pieces of legislation are missing to put it into practice. The solutions offered by the state offer neither immediate nor long-term security and perspective to the victims. The police are often helpless, as the abuser can only be kept away from the person at risk by a court order. In such cases, it would be a burning need for the court to investigate the situation within 24 hours instead of 72 hours and issue a court order keeping the abuser away from the victim. At the same time, there is a need to create a legal network that allows the victim to receive adequate legal protection even if he or she is socially disadvantaged and, most often, financially dependent on the abuser. I welcome and support the report's call on the Commission and the Member States to introduce zero tolerance for all forms of violence.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, gender equality must not be just a slogan. It must be a reality and here we are talking about gender equality in all aspects: pay, holding management positions, accessing European funds, accessing bank loans, in politics, but even in advertising. The gender dimension must also be taken into account in policies to combat violence, including sexual violence and harassment at work, and here is my last example, with my colleague Pavel, with almost 7,500 women experiencing sexual violence in Italy. The promotion of gender equality also needs a budget, Commissioner, and I therefore consider it pertinent to request funding for specific measures involving non-governmental organizations, local and regional authorities for education. Gender imbalance, in fact, can be seen in the European institutions and I think it is necessary both at national and European level to find ways to balance. Unfortunately, in recent years, we have witnessed an unfortunate setback in the implementation of gender equality policies. That is why I consider it important to regularly evaluate and establish concrete measures. Gender equality is everyone's responsibility.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! It is depressing that in the debate on equality, in the debate on women's rights, several people, especially on the left-hand side of the room, spoke of so-called abortion as a woman's right. Obviously abortion is an act of violence, primarily against the unborn child, but we do not realize to what extent abortion legislation itself is a source of coercion against women. If the so-called abortion is done by law, the mother may be persuaded by the feral partner, may be persuaded by the family, may also, unfortunately - which is particularly dramatic - be persuaded by a doctor, and often fall victim to structural pressure. The whole abortion mentality created by this legislation causes the woman to be cornered. It is also depressing - and this is the top of everything - that doctors who want to respect and protect life have been attacked many times here. Repeated postulates of compulsion against doctors to practice abortion is a very dangerous symptom of totalitarian tendencies of the European Union.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I strongly agree with all of you who said here repeatedly, many times, that we need to act in this policy of gender equality with a sense of urgency. We desperately need to see progress. But it is not only progress in terms of statistical data, but also progress in terms of improving the atmosphere in our society. And here you all know that we are in a very difficult era of a worsening atmosphere in society, so we need to be much stronger in combating all the factors which create this worsening, including online, which is a big topic that has not been covered here. However, I strongly disagree that what we do is only words. We take a lot of concrete actions. By the way, apart from words, what is stronger than the words we have? I esteem so much, I value so highly the fact that President Tajani today apologised for the shameful statement which we heard here last week. These are strong words which show the whole of Europe the values we stand for. It is very important that we are brave enough to say the words we believe in, and we do a lot of concrete things to fulfil the promises we make. The debate showed that we are addressing the proper problems with our strategic engagement, because as you know, there are four priorities: equal pay for equal work; increased employment of women and their economic independence; relevant representation of women in decision-making positions; and significantly decrease the level and scope of violence against women in Europe. We need to use all the instruments we have, not just legislation. You have also rightly declared here repeatedly that what we need is proper enforcement of the current legislation. We have a lot of anti-discrimination pieces of legislation, and we need to be much better in enforcement. We also have to use other instruments to better target the problem in individual Member States. That is why we are more frequently using the so-called country-specific recommendations, which last year addressed the specific problems in Member States. But we need to address the issue of the atmosphere in society. We need better funding; we need to fund proper campaigning to address the main problems. You know that we are now organising a very strong – and I would say loud – campaign which shows that we have the goal of zero tolerance to violence against women. We are funding and we are organising the campaign in all the Member States, again targeting specific forms of violence in the Member States. I would like to say that in the proposals of this Commission you can hardly find any cases of positive discrimination. Please, read the latest version of the Women on boards directive. This is gender neutral. We want diversity on boards. You cannot find anything which could be called social engineering. Believe me, as somebody coming from a former totalitarian country, I am extremely sensitive about this, and in our package to enable the people to better combine work duties and family life, we are very careful to open up the choices so that people can choose how they want to live. If mothers want to stay at home with the children, they can. If they want to go to work, they should not be prevented from doing so by the barriers which are still present in the EU. This is why I am very sensitive about everybody who criticises the Commission for engaging in social engineering, because simply it is not true, and I am happy to present this in the new package on work-life balance. Last comment on EU funds: I worked for almost 20 years in the field of EU funding, and I remember times when there was a goal which was called gender equality. As applicants for the money, we were ticking the boxes: gender-equal project? Yes! It was so artificial and so discouraging for all those who really wanted to do something to help gender equality. I am one hundred per cent for better use of EU funds, better policy and better achievement of goals in gender equality, but let us do it in an effective and efficient way so that we are not using the EU money for counterproductive results. So thank you for your comments. After every discussion on gender equality, I am more encouraged and more inspired to do the everyday work. I am looking forward to further cooperation with you.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: speaker. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the contributions to the debate. I think it has been an important debate. Sometimes I have to admit that I have the feeling that, as a relatively young person who takes many things for granted in our society, sometimes we find ourselves defending elements of equality between men and women that we thought we had already achieved, and having to face demonstrations like that of our Polish colleague - as many of you have mentioned - it is obviously deeply shocking. By the way, I would like to take this opportunity to thank Avaaz's campaign to collect signatures in favor of sanctions against the deputy - which I think a lot of people have signed - and also, therefore, urge Mr. Tajani to have this sanction, which he will announce this week, be as forceful as possible. What I would like to do is invite everyone, parliamentarians, but also especially the Commission and the Council ... Look, we have two options: or wait 50 or 70 years to reach equality in terms of the pay gap, pension gap, etc., which are the calculations that the Commission itself has made about what period we will need at the current rate, or do something. And doing something means getting down to work on one thing the commissioner has said: better apply the legislation. Yes, but also, Commissioner, making laws is important. I already know that many things do not depend on you, most things are blocked in the Council. We are perfectly aware, but we do wish that, at the very least, we could work hand in hand with the Commission and Parliament to get some things done in the Council. Look, if in this legislature we managed to get the Council to unblock the Directive on quotas in the Boards of Directors and finish the ratification by all the Member States of the Istanbul Convention, it would at least be a good sign that the issue of equality of genre It is on the table again, since now we have the feeling that it has ceased to be.It is no longer on the table of governments or the European Union or anyone else and, with the data we have, it is more urgent than ever that it should be a top priority again.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen! Firstly, I would like to thank once again all those who contributed to the final version of the report on equal rights for women and men in access to goods and services. Not only parliamentarians, but also advisers, the administration, which also worked very hard. As our discussion today is of a ritualistic nature, I would like to draw your attention to two general matters in this conclusion. First, the absolutely crucial issue - and this is also emerging from today's discussion - is to deal with the work-home tension, this home-work conflict that has dragged on from the very beginning. The first emancipated women fought for the right to education and to work, and today we here in Parliament, with the matter largely settled, are fighting for the right to motherhood and to have a family on some rational terms. Let it not be a double job, that it would not be a double burden on women, but that it would be more just and rational. This issue of reconciliation is absolutely crucial. I very much appreciate and look forward to the further action of the European Commission on the roadmap on this matter. The issue of maternity and parental leaves, flexible working hours, the home worker market, nurseries, kindergartens and nursing homes is also always topical. The second thing that is absolutely crucial is respect for the law. We really do have the right to equal treatment of women and men and to equality in many places, but this right is still not implemented. Commissioner! It calls for hard provisions, very specific provisions, not recommendations. Because every time we have recommendations, we are met with disregard, non-respect, omission or bad interpretation. If we only have a recommendation and not a hard recipe, there will always be some Korwin-Mikke that he had wanted to be the misogynist king here a week ago.He's not with us today.Probably on TV or radio.I would also like to call on the media not to invite people who are sexists who do not represent Parliament's position and that they do not promote such an attitude.

name: Clare Moody
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, this has been a very interesting debate. It is notable that each of the rapporteurs and many of the speakers have pointed out that we are at best stagnating on equality between women and men and, in many ways, we are going backwards. We should, of course, celebrate the ongoing achievements of the EU in support of women. Indeed, frequently, it is only EU funds that ensure that support. But we must move away from assuming that simply having specific programmes aimed means ‘job done’ and that somehow that alone delivers equality. It won’t! I welcome the Commissioner’s recognition that this report is timely in relation to discussions on the EU budget, and that we should use all means available. The budget must be seen as part of those ‘all means’. If we are to make progress, we have to adopt gender mainstreaming across the whole budget, using the many gender budgeting tools that have been proven to work. Unless we recognise the hidden and unintended consequences of the way the budget is used, we will always fail to address our goal of defeating inequality. Thank you for all the support that has been expressed for this report. I look forward to the vote tomorrow, but even more, I look forward to the action to follow-up on the report’s recommendations.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 14 March 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - From the necessary legal equality between men and women to the narrow-minded egalitarianism that nature contests, there is only one step that the European Union happily takes. The report on equality between women and men carried by Ernest Urtasun is proof of this. Positive discrimination, in addition to being contrary to republican principles now in force in France, is always exercised to the detriment of someone. Imposing quotas for women in positions of responsibility could be unfair to some men. Only individual merit counts. The report introduces exotic notions, having only distant connections to its main object. By wishing to impose an agenda that is more a matter of cultural battle than a real social policy, the report downgrades the real issues. What are they ? Put an end to the euro-austerity spiral which plunges young women into precariousness. Increase the supply of childcare, so that women can continue to work. An imperative given the continental demographic decline. Finally, continue to fight against the practices of another age that have come from abroad: excisions, the full veil or forced marriages.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up. - Despite the fact that gender equality is an explicit goal of several sections of the Union budget, being addressed in 15 directives that have been adopted at EU level, I believe that the concrete commitment to continue gender mainstreaming needs to be accelerated, as existing policies have have been implemented to a small extent, and the budgetary resources allocated especially for gender issues are insufficient. I believe that it is vital to promote the consistent idea of ​​integrating the gender dimension throughout the budgetary procedure in both European and national strategies, in order to allow the evaluation of the overall EU budget and from a gender perspective. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the European Fund for Strategic Investments does not contain a gender perspective, and if this direction were implemented, the European Union could certainly use its budgetary resources much more effectively to act towards this goal so important.

name: María
text: Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE), in writing. - Article 23 of our Charter of Fundamental Rights recognizes equality between men and women and foresees taking measures in favor of "the less represented sex. More references to gender gaps that harm men and boys are missing in this report. It is rarer that legal measures are stipulated when the sex less represented or more harmed is the male. We talk about the historically unfair "glass ceiling" that women encounter, but pay less attention to other areas of work and life where men and boys are hardest hit: workplace accidents, suicide risk, school failure , etc. Men are also disproportionately affected in certain areas of health, are more vulnerable to risky behaviors, have weaker social networks, and report less of the violence they experience. Some of these indicators are reflected in the statistics of the report itself. I believe that these gender imbalances in our initiatives end up harming men and women, since it is together that we can build a freer and more equal society.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: In written form. - Mr President, I consider the call of the report on equality between women and men in the European Union for 2014-2015 on investing in the care of children and the elderly to be particularly important, as I believe that we must take into account the special role of working women who bear a double burden of responsibilities - not only in relation to their workplace, but also in relation to family and household care. The availability of quality and affordable childcare facilities is one of the prerequisites for the active inclusion of women in the labor market and public life. The lack of equality in the labor market and the fact that a large number of employed women work part-time lead to losses for the European economy. I therefore call on the Member States to consider possible means of providing more employment opportunities for women by providing more and more accessible childcare facilities so that they are not faced with a career or family choice.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: written. - Women are less intelligent and weaker, says MEP Korwin-Mikke. I assume that Mr. Mikke feels threatened, and that is why he is so around him. But here's the shocking thing: even disregarding his comments, the EIGE gives the EU a score of 5.3 for the year 2015, and only 3.8 in “time”. "On average, 77% of women in the EU spend at least one hour cooking and housework every day, compared to only 24% of men." In addition to paid work, women often do extra hours of work at home to take care of others. In this way they negate themselves and thus reduce their chances on the labor market and economic independence. Weaker and smaller? He will mean a greater sense of duty, greater social pressure and much less help. These findings confirm the importance of measures for a better reconciliation of work and private life for women and men. With good care and reception for children and other dependents, and flexible working arrangements. I would therefore ask the Commission to come up with an ambitious work-life balance package as soon as possible, including proposals for better paternity, maternity and parental leave.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Ladies and gentlemen!Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental principles of the European Union enshrined in the Treaties.It should be understood primarily as non-discrimination (i.e. equal opportunities) and equal pay for equal work.This also applies to access to goods and services, where women should not be discriminated against in any way, as is often the case in particular with regard to pregnancy and motherhood.At the same time, it must be ensured that women's pensions are not lower than men's pensions.Unfortunately, at present - on a pan-European scale - women's pensions are 39% lower than men's pensions.It is unfair and discriminatory against women.Member States and EU institutions should take effective action to change this situation.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: written. - Mister President! 30 years until as many women as men work. 40 years until the division of domestic work between both sexes turns out equally. And 70 years until women and men are paid equally. On International Women's Day last week, the European Parliament once again focused on the economic emancipation of women. But our fight for equality cannot be confined to one day; it must be a priority in our political decisions throughout the year. The care of children and older relatives must be divided equally. It is not fair to let women do this task largely free of charge! We need to rethink the financial valuation of typical women's jobs and adjust their pay to the level of typical men's jobs. And we must ensure through more transparency in payment that women do not earn less than men in the same job with the same qualifications. This is the only way we can address some of the still gaping inequalities. The EU Commission is now called upon to include our demands on parental, maternity and paternity leave and to give the go-ahead for better gender equality with the corresponding new proposals for directives.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - Equality between women and men is a fundamental right enshrined in the Treaty on European Union and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, but it is sad that in some Member States women are treated as secondary actors. Unfortunately, we also hear shameful, gender-discriminatory statements here within the walls of the EP. It is our basic duty to take action against them! Zero tolerance for gender-based harassment, whether at home, at work or in other environments! I consider EU funding to be a good tool in this fight and in promoting gender equality, and the report takes a good approach by examining the three different funds. The 2014-2020 budget period hardly deals with gender equality, and in the future, in order to strengthen transparency and democratic quality, external experts must be involved during the budgetary procedure.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: written. - The EU is the world leader in women's rights. Yet we should not think that the battle is over. Research shows that we are only halfway through gender equality and that progress is slow. Equal Pay Day was "celebrated" on March 14. Women in Belgium still earn on average 20% less than men. So they have to start working ten years earlier in order to receive the same wage. But the pension gap also remains unacceptably large. Many women involuntarily work part-time because of gender stereotype expectations or because they work in precarious statutes. Addressing this is essential on the road to gender equality. Extending paternity and parental leave and encouraging fathers to make more use of them is necessary in order to achieve a more equal division of care responsibilities in the family. There is also an important role for employers here. They must create a corporate culture that does not prevent fathers from taking up their right to parental leave. Finally, promoting gender equality is also about fighting gender stereotypes across society from an early age. For example, there are still many gender stereotypes to be found in school books or reading books. We must stop this.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Ana Gomes' report on the consequences of mass data for fundamental rights: privacy, data protection, non-discrimination, security and law enforcement (2016/2225 (INI)) (A8-0044 / 2017).

name: Ana Gomes
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, the European Parliament is going to vote on the report I wrote on the implications of big data, or “big data”, on fundamental rights: privacy, data protection, non-discrimination, security and law enforcement. I am grateful for the contribution of all shadow rapporteurs, officials, assistants and experts who collaborated in writing this report. We recognize that the data revolution is there, driven by the progress of communication technologies and the ubiquity of electronic devices that allow the storage of data about our lives, collected in mass, constantly growing and used without control by public and private entities. As scientist Tim Berners-Lee warned yesterday, the most pressing risks associated with mass data processing and algorithmic decision making are many and include security breaches, unauthorized access, illegal surveillance, discrimination and price differentiation, as well as decision-making and adoption of public policies based on poorly representative erroneous data. We therefore propose solutions: investment in digital literacy, creation of ethical standards and transparency in the use of algorithms, cooperation between the public, private and non-governmental sectors, betting on technologies that privilege privacy and data security, mechanisms for account protection and clearing, to name just a few. More urgent than ever is the protection of reliable and rigorous sources of information, at a time when algorithms have an increasing impact on the information made available to citizens, which can pervert, endanger, fundamental rights to information, as well as freedom of the media and pluralism. We have, in the European Union, the most advanced legal framework in the world with regard to data protection and privacy, embodied in the General Data Protection Regulation - a standard of legal certainty, which is beneficial and useful to the private sector in the European Union and globally.Everything now depends on the seriousness with which we take its application and compliance.This report gives Parliament's contribution and points out a way of balancing the interests and fundamental rights of citizens with the needs of businesses.The public and legal debate will certainly continue.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President.Following the recent US election, a series of articles has emerged highlighting the risks to the democratic process posed by technological advances in big data processing.Critical elements of this threat are the mass proliferation of smartphones and the supported growth of people's involvement in social networks on the Internet.Data shared via social networks on the Internet enables the creation of increasingly accurate personal profiles of individual citizens.The result is a blurring of the line between the provision of information and targeted manipulative propaganda.It is therefore high time to talk about these risks and also look for legislative instruments that would increase the protection of European citizens from both virtual and real threats.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the opportunities offered by big data are founded only after the protection of fundamental rights, compliance with data production legislation and legal certainty. These principles have informed many of my questions, with which I first of all asked for the protection of fundamental rights in public services and for people with disabilities and for the reduction of inequalities in treatment. In my opinion, a year ago the challenges here in the European Parliament ran along three fundamental lines: first, the ethical and moral questions connected to medical science for the use of big data with awareness and caution, provided that it is capable of creating intelligence artificial and applied to neuroscience. Second, the regulation of the flow connected to the use of devices that exploit big data with privacy aspects that are really at risk. Third, security against cybercrime would be, which plays on the unclear distinction between sensitive and non-sensitive data and supports the unintentional release of data. I therefore approve the report which expresses a state of great prudence and caution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, the prospects and opportunities offered by mass data can be fully exploited by citizens, companies, governments and institutions, provided that public confidence in these technologies is ensured through strict respect for human rights. fundamental rights and legal certainty for all stakeholders. Freedom must not be subordinated to the profit of companies, it must not be subordinated to the altar of insurance companies, it must not be subordinated to the interests of banks. We see that companies hold consumer data and use it for speculation. Some companies create consumer profiles, borrower profiles, insured profiles, employee profiles. Transparency, objectivity and accountability as well as the control of personal data are key values ​​from which specific rights and obligations derive. The protection of personal information is a fundamental right and any processing of personal data is prohibited ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! Big data brings us many advantages, but it must also be clear that a large amount of data can also mean a lot of personal data and that in these cases it is always clear: data protection must be observed, even when it comes to big data. Applications goes. We have laid down clear lines with the General Data Protection Regulation. And we have to continue on this path, because that is the prerequisite for trust in such new applications. We also need the same for security. It must be clear that when such applications are designed and brought to market, liability rules also apply there, for example for security gaps that arise. And in the end there must be limits. In the police, for example, it cannot be that a big data algorithm alone determines whether I am a suspect or not. We cannot foresee people and their actions, but we can assess how, for example, places will be designed or how certain processes will take place, but not people.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Mr President, I am not satisfied with this report.Data protection means that the data belongs to whoever issues it.This means leaving the current economic model, in which the data is exploited and the one who provides it is not associated with the results and does not control his process.We must also locate the data in Europe - you did not specify it - otherwise the data no longer belongs to us, according to the rules that America has given itself.We have to master the software and hardware chain, because otherwise the data will also escape us through technology.Finally, you are not talking about the data of companies, the looting that is done, including in everything related to open science.This report is therefore not satisfactory.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the rapid development of communication technology and the widespread use of electronic devices enable various bodies to collect and process personal data, which they do without the consent of the parties concerned. After all, recent revelations, leaked by Wikileaks, of the methods used by the CIA to gather information are recent. No one has the right to infringe on the personal life of an individual and to collect information which he or she will use against him or her either to blackmail him or her, to use violence, or even more so to give it to various multinational corporations, thus contributing in the establishment of monopolies. This is an unacceptable phenomenon. The European Union must deal with this and the rights of the citizens of European countries must be protected.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the positive effects and the opportunities brought by data analytics are already visible in areas where there is energy efficiency, fight against climate change, transport or health care. It can help optimise businesses, improve public services and enhance the quality of our lives. When browsing or making online purchases, most people are not aware to whom they give away their data. No wonder that according to Eurostat, 81% of Europeans are concerned about the control of information they provide about themselves. As is the case with every new technology, the effects of big data analytics depends on the purpose it is put to serve. In order to maintain trust, it is essential to make sure that it is not misused, for example to deny health insurance or bank loans for certain categories of people based on their online search history. As the report clearly points out, it is up to us to guarantee transparency, due process and legal certainty in the processing of personal data.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the European Union's data-driven economy has been estimated at almost three hundred billion euros. It can help create more than seven million jobs by 2020, if the rate of more than 5% annual growth continues in the future. That is why it is important to adjust our policies in such a way as to ensure the balance between the development need of this sector, on the one hand, and the protection of user data, on the other. In this regard, the management of megadata must be linked to the five fundamental rights highlighted in this report: the right to privacy, data protection, the principles of non-discrimination, security and law enforcement. However, the development of the sector must not be hampered by abuses by certain individuals, companies or institutions, and if these situations occur, they must be severely punished, according to a set of common rules at European level. However, the presumption of innocence for those who process the data must also prevail in this area. Therefore, the best solution remains to invest in digital education and data management from an early age.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, today’s debate on big data and its fundamental rights implications, in particular on data protection, non-discrimination and law enforcement is very timely and important. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Gomes, and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs for having dedicated their time and energy to this topic. We are facing a new technological revolution driven by big data, artificial intelligence and robotics. Big data and artificial intelligence holds huge potential for our strong industrial base and for the public sector and can help solve societal challenges, whether it is better health care, combating climate change and protecting the environment, more efficient transport, agricultural productivity – and the list can go on. As with any major technological development, there are significant challenges that we must deal with. I fully share the focus of the Parliament on the need to ensure trust. Big data needs a high level of personal data protection and strong security. In this regard the EU data protection reform the Parliament and Council adopted last year sets the highest data protection standards in the world. For example, the regulation reinforces the tools allowing people to keep control over the use of their personal data. It will be easier for citizens to obtain the rectification or deletion of personal data. The regulation also introduces the right to portability and clarifies the notions of consent, profiling and transparency. Data protection by design and data protection by default become essential principles. This helps businesses to develop new methods for security and protection of personal data. For the use of big data analytics, anonymisation and pseudonymisation are very important. The General Data Protection Regulation promotes the use of such measures, rendering impossible the identification of the individual and disguising the identity of the person while keeping the data retraceable. Data security measures such as encryption are also a useful tool to adequately protect personal data. As regards law enforcement, the data protection police directive stresses that where decisions with legal effects are taken on individuals, they are given the right to obtain human intervention. The principles of data processing, such as purpose limitation, no excessive collection, data security must be fully respected. In order to ensure that the legal framework is properly applied from its entry into application in May 2018, the Commission’s focus is to work with Member States – with the data protection authorities as well as with businesses and civil society – to ensure that the rules are well understood and that they will be applied in a uniform way all over the European Union. We will also develop awareness-raising activities for citizens. The new rules also require that an appropriate level of security for personal data processing is ensured, depending on the risks and type of processing. And this is also a fundamental data protection principle. Overall, cyber security is also important to ensure confidence, and the EU Network and Information Security Directive is also due for implementation next year. Furthermore, the Commission looks forward to the discussions and adoption of the e-privacy Regulation, which will increase trust in electronic communications services – trust and protection, which must go hand in hand. Finally, the Commission is currently looking at how to ensure the free flow of non-personal data across sectors and across borders within the EU. The Communication entitled Building a European Data Economy was adopted on 10 January this year, and an online public consultation has been launched and is running until 26 April. In the near future, most economic activity will depend on data, but if data cannot move freely, our growth potential is limited. The Communication looks at unjustified data location restrictions, access to data and how more data can become available for use and reuse. The more we have data availability and the more data is used, the better the data economy will develop. It is clear that alongside an adequate legal framework it is essential to take into consideration the ethical dimension of such activities. This is a shared concern across the world, and as politicians we have to remain vigilant on all these aspects.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Stefan Eck's report on minimum requirements for the protection of farm rabbits (2016/2077 (INI)) (A8-0011 / 2017).

name: Stefan Eck
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! Rabbits are number two of the most farmed livestock in the EU. However, the sector only generates 1.1% of total European meat production. But we also need binding regulations for niche products, especially when animal welfare and food safety are affected. In 2005, EFSA pointed out that the mortality and disease rate of fattening rabbits is significantly higher than that of all other livestock species - in particular due to the unsuitable battery cages that do not meet the natural needs of these animals. For this reason, the use of antibiotics in high doses is also the rule. I do not need to explain in detail what this means in terms of antibiotic resistance. There is legislation that provides minimum standards for the protection of pigs, calves, laying hens and broilers. But there is no single piece of legislation on minimum standards for the protection of rabbits. In addition, there has been a steady decline in the demand for rabbit meat in recent years, and not without reason. Consumers are demanding higher animal welfare standards, which the Eurobarometer 442 on the attitude of Europeans towards animal welfare made very clear. Consumers want more food safety and they want high quality products. More and more consumers are boycotting rabbit meat because it has become known the cruel conditions under which rabbits are kept. It is not for nothing that more than 600,000 animal lovers from all over Europe petitioned the Commission and the Council to ban battery cages last year. With the own-initiative report, I have pursued the following goals: Firstly, to harmonize the internal market and to respond to consumer wishes for safe food and more animal welfare, in particular by gradually phasing out battery cage management without neglecting the interests of the industry, and secondly, reducing the extreme suffering of this species by introducing animal welfare standards; thirdly, to draw the public's attention to the cruel conditions in rabbit fattening farms. The last goal has already been achieved. The media have taken up the topic and intend to report on the intolerable conditions. The present own-initiative report will of course also be in focus. It is a question of the credibility of this Parliament if a decision is made to ban battery cages for laying hens, but - like the EPP - everything is done to ensure that this method of keeping rabbits is retained for an indefinite period of time. You have to be very far from reality if you don't realize that my own-initiative report does justice to the demand for safe food, the improvement of animal welfare standards and the precarious situation of breeders. But how does the EPP react? Last week she launched an alternative motion for a resolution to thwart a legal provision for a gradual phase-out from battery cage management under all circumstances - in the election year 2017! What is to be made of the European agricultural and animal welfare policy, in which an animal species is deliberately forgotten and these animals suffer immeasurably because there is no legislation? Animal welfare must not degenerate into mere lip service? When we vote on the report in the morning, we should bear in mind that it would be a fatal sign if the European Parliament simply disregarded the wishes of consumers and the requests of animal lovers in a time of ever increasing allegations of remote citizenship. I hope that the citizens of the EU and the 330 million rabbits and rabbit breeders can count on a majority in this House tomorrow. Quit that The age of cages for rabbits is now - it's high time!
