name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I want to subscribe to this report and thus give it my full support here, because I am pleased that, in addition to protecting human rights, the European Parliament is also addressing other living species and animal welfare. And I'm very glad that we are dealing with the living conditions of rabbits here. In general, I would like to say that any cage farming for any kind of animal is very inhumane, and we should do our utmost to bring cage farming to an end in Europe. That is why I support this report, and it seems logical to me, as the rapporteur has already said, that if we have banned certain cage farming, for example in chickens, something similar should be the case for rabbits. After all, in my country, the Czech Republic, we are now debating the ban on cage farming for fur animals, such as foxes and minks, and it is causing great emotion, and I would very much like this topic to be discussed here in the EP here in the future. . So animal welfare is an important issue in European civilization, and I support it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that the Commission, in the light of the high number of rabbits reared and slaughtered in the European Union and the serious implications for animal welfare of the farming systems in use, must come forward as soon as possible legislative proposals aimed at the phasing out of battery cages across the European Union. Specific diseases and the high mortality rate due to the appalling conditions in which rabbits are kept have often necessitated a massive and widespread preventive administration of antibiotics, making rabbits farming, in its current form, also problematic for health. Human. The systematic use of drugs to compensate for the inadequacy of the environmental and sanitary conditions of intensive farming should be prohibited and other types of rabbit farming such as Park systems, improved free-range farming and organic farming should be promoted. These alternatives to intensive cage farming would ensure animal welfare but also reduce the use of antibiotics and the consequent spread of antimicrobial resistance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, despite the fact that rabbits are the second largest population of farmed animals in the European Union and more than 340 million rabbits are slaughtered annually, the European Union does not yet have specific legislation to establish rules for the protection of rabbits. At present, in several Member States of the Union, rabbits are bred in horrific conditions on breeding and fattening farms, which is in stark contrast to animal welfare requirements. Since 2005 it has been found that there are poor living conditions as well as high mortality and morbidity rates among rabbits raised in Europe in several rabbit farms. It is therefore in the interest of rabbit farmers and the industry as a whole, but also in the interest of consumers, that rabbit farming, in accordance with the European production model, must meet the highest standards of food safety, health and well-being. animals and respect for the environment.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, rabbits are, in Europe, the second most exploited animal species, with Spain, together with France and Italy, being the countries with the highest production.In factory farms they live miserable, brutally short, sick lives, and are unable to express their species' behaviors.Considering that almost all of these animals are crammed into such small spaces that they cannot jump or stretch normally, some countries have already taken measures in this regard, such as, for example, Belgium.Therefore, it is also time for the European Union to adopt its own legislation in favor of the welfare of rabbits.That is why I have tabled, together with Stefan Eck, the amendment for European legislation in this regard, and I call on all MEPs to support it, as well as the report.Tens of thousands of people in Europe demand it and millions of living beings need it.No more cages.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, it has already been reported that rabbits are the second largest farmed animal in the European Union, yet there is no legislation to protect them. Thus, in almost all European countries, rabbits are bred under miserable conditions, and this, combined with the fact that they are afflicted with various diseases and antibiotics are used to treat these diseases, endangers the health of consumers. That is why the European Union must support the rapporteur's suggestion, who rightly denounces the fact that rabbits are kept in cages - which is unacceptable - and must be raised in a protected environment, ie a protected park. . This will ensure that these animals do not suffer and that the health of consumers is not endangered.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, like all my colleagues, I have received hundreds of emails in the last two weeks asking me to support a ban on caging rabbits.I am very pleased with such an expression of interest in the work of this Parliament.But at the same time, I can't help but feel sad.We have no problem setting European standards for the conditions in which rabbits, chickens or horses live, but when it comes to the conditions in which people live, there is suddenly silence.I would like to believe that there will come a time when the mailboxes of Members of the European Parliament will be flooded with requests to introduce minimum standards for the conditions in which European Union citizens live.I know that we need to take care of animal welfare, but we should care more about people.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I was the shadow rapporteur for this report, together with my colleague Eck, and I want to say on behalf of the PPE that I believe that we have achieved a minimum level of agreement on the standards in rabbit farming.I think that these minimum standards should not be a general dictation, but should really include the lowest level at which we are able to agree across the political spectrum.And the question here is whether rabbits should be kept in enriched cages or whether they should be kept in other cruel conditions, certainly not.I do not want to encourage rabbits to be reared in a way that really affects their good standard of living, their good quality of life, but I believe that we need to promote a balance between the rights of farmers, breeders and rabbits.I think that, in this sense, satisfaction has been made in this report.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first let me thank the rapporteur, Mr Eck, for his report on minimum standards for the protection of farm rabbits. The report provides a comprehensive overview of all dimensions of the welfare of farm rabbits. Animal welfare forms an important part of the priorities of the Commissioner for Health and Food Safety. The report encourages the Commission to take a number of non-legislative actions such as drawing up a roadmap to include guidelines on good practices and a Commission recommendation relating to rabbit health, welfare and housing. The report also invites the Commission to use scientific evidence as the basis for proposing new measures for housing requirements, for breeding does and for rabbits reared for meat production. I would remind the honourable Members that all farmed animal species, including rabbits, are protected by the rules of Directive 98/58 concerning the protection of animals kept for farming purposes. The directive requires that farmers take all responsible steps to ensure that animals under their care are not caused unnecessary pain, suffering or injury. In addition, in 2005 the European Food Safety Authority published an opinion on the impact of the current housing and husbandry systems on the health and welfare of farmed domestic rabbits. This opinion provides Member States and farmers with data on aspects of farming systems which may put the welfare of the rabbits at risk. The rules of the directive should be seen in conjunction with this opinion. Rabbit production in the EU is essentially concentrated in a few Member States mainly Italy, Spain and France. Against this background and in line with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the Commission takes the view that the Member States involved are better placed to address the relevant issues concerning rabbit production. As honourable Members will know, Member States are primarily responsible for the implementation of EU legislation. Better enforcement of the EU animal welfare legislation is one of the key priorities for animal welfare, and the Commission has invested substantial resources in pursuit of this aim. This priority is particularly relevant because we continue to see a widespread lack of compliance regarding animal welfare rules across many Member States. In consideration of this analysis and given its limited resources, the Commission does not consider it appropriate to propose an initiative on the welfare of farm rabbits. However, the Commission remains open to considering the topic within the framework of the newly established European Animal Welfare Platform, provided there is sufficient commitment among the stakeholders to make progress in this area.

text: in writing. - Parliament will decide on the advisability of setting minimum standards, in particular via European legislation, for the protection of farmed rabbits and the gradual disappearance of conventional cages. The risk is to make our production disappear in Europe and to depend exclusively on Chinese imports whose standards are not necessarily ours. Faced with a very ideological report, containing factual errors and unbalanced, I suggest that the PPE Group table an alternative resolution. In addition, considering the weight of rabbit production in Europe (4 member countries and 1.1% of meat production) and the very wide divergence of approach between the States, European legislation would bring no added value by virtue of principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - In a survey carried out in the summer of 2014 in sixteen rabbit farms in five Member States, the NGO "CIWF France" underlined the dire conditions of the 340 million rabbits raised in the European Union. Confined in wire cages the size of an A4 sheet, causing intense stress in animals, rabbits are said to be the farm animals most exposed to antibiotics. The text under debate therefore aims at the gradual abandonment of battery breeding. It remedies a legal vacuum: indeed, rabbit farming is governed by Directive 98/58 / EC of 20 July 1998, but is not the subject of any specific text, unlike pigs, calves, laying hens or broilers. I welcome the consideration of the material situation of breeders. Thus, under the terms of this text, financial support may be granted to them from European funds from the rural development component in order to facilitate the transition to a new method of breeding, replacing, in particular, battery breeding by battery breeding. enclosure. In particular, the Commission will have to promote the consumption of rabbit meat, of which the European Union is the second largest producer in the world.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written. - Rabbits are the second most common type of farmed livestock in the EU, but only represent 1.1% of total meat production in the EU. At present there is no specific legislation on minimum standards for the protection of rabbits. Austria created better framework conditions for the animals as early as 2012, for example by banning battery cages from production. This pioneering role is also expressly emphasized in the report on minimum requirements for the protection of farm rabbits. An EU-wide legal provision that benefits animals, farmers and consumers is to be advocated from our perspective. The abolition of the battery cages and the dignified handling of the animals associated with them, a shorter and more comfortable transport and slaughter under anesthesia with the least possible stress are those points that were particularly important to us for animal welfare reasons and which were also met by the report. The report benefits the consumers because, on the one hand, the need for antibiotics would decrease through a switch from cage breeding to enclosure systems. On the other hand, the consumer's conscience also plays a role, e.g. B. to buy rabbit meat from an animal-friendly or animal-worthy breed. In turn, the farmers are to be awarded a corresponding compensation due to the conversion and the possible additional costs.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Julie Girling's report on the responsible husbandry and care of equidae (2016/2078 (INI)) (A8-0014 / 2017).

name: Julie Girling
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, throughout European history the bond between equidae and humankind has occupied a very unique position within our societies. As many of you know, equidae have and still do play a vital role in many EU Member States. Sometimes this is out of necessity, as forms of transportation and agricultural assistance, but other newer roles have also emerged such as in research, therapy and rehabilitation. For example, in Bristol, in my constituency in the UK, Spiritus Equis offers equine-assisted therapy to help young people with substance misuse and offending behaviour. Equidae – horses in particular – are also prominent in the betting and sporting world, and for many owners, myself included, equidae are kept for leisure and more recreational purposes. Through such versatility, equidae have come to possess vast economic potential. Today the equine sector adds over EUR 100 billion to the EU’s economy each year and is a leading rural employer in many EU Member States. However, despite the varied roles, close relationship and at times dependency we share with these animals, in too many cases equidae are faced with a number of severe welfare concerns that serve to adversely impact the entire sector. Such concerns include neglect, overwork and inappropriate living conditions. These problems can be found across the breadth of the equid sector and occur due to a multitude of reasons: ignorance, lack of education, over-breeding and economic hardship. Europe’s citizens want to see more action on animal welfare. With this report I believe that we have a golden opportunity to not only substantially improve the lives of the seven million equidae currently living within the EU, but also by better caring for these animals we have a chance to unlock the full economic potential of this sector and provide a much-needed boost to the rural economy. It is a win-win for all involved. I would like to emphasise at this point that this report does not intend to call for additional legislation but rather to improve existing provisions, particularly their enforcement. In fact, equidae are broadly covered by a number of legislative acts pertaining to their health and welfare, and whilst better implementation and enforcement of existing law would help remedy some of these problems, it is not clear within the scope of the existing treaties where added European legislation could, or should, add value. Rather, I firmly believe – and this is a belief that fundamentally shapes the nature of this report – that value can be added by tackling ignorance and by encouraging and facilitating the spread of best practice and good guidance. This will provide both commercial and recreational equidae owners with the tools and knowledge to better meet the needs of their animals. For example, knowledge transfer schemes as we see in Ireland are one tool Member States could utilise to share best practices, as well as business models and to foster innovation and new ideas. This is especially important in light of the added emphasis on the need – and, in fact, urgency – to become more environmentally-friendly, a development that the equid sector is not immune to. Such schemes could therefore safeguard the welfare needs of equidae while, at the same time, ensure businesses are viable and are able to adapt to changes in regulation elsewhere. The development of animal welfare indicators will provide the guidance needed to make compliance and consistent enforcement more achievable. An increased number of educational resources will tackle ignorance and thereby correct the current lack of understanding surrounding the care and ownership of equidae. The establishment of animal welfare reference centres will provide a much-needed avenue for the dissemination of guidance. A recommitment from the Commission to the development of a European charter for sustainable and responsible tourism would also be hugely beneficial. Tourists would be empowered to make choices, which will not only reward those enterprises which properly care for their equidae but will also inform and provide peace of mind. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the shadow for all their support and constructive contributions and to thank Eurogroup for Animals who have been a valuable source of information throughout the process.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, we keep five horses at home, so these animals are very nice to me. I have to say that I really want to take care of their well-being together with you, I suppose. But I would also like to emphasize that the rapporteur has said that we do not find ourselves in any legal vacuum when breeding horses. There is a legal basis here, which can be used for horse breeding. In this sense, this report is clearly different from the one we discussed in the previous point, that is, the call for new legislation on rabbit farming. I would like to say that I also see strong moments in that report, and that is, for example, the support of the rural economy from the breeding of these animals, because both in the field of tourism, the breeding of these animals can be used a lot. The rapporteur has also touched on the problematic area, such as the transport of these animals. I think that report is excellent and I am happy to support it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I congratulate Mrs Girling on her excellent report. I will deal with a slightly different aspect from that of animal welfare, which has already been well related: the issue of labeling and traceability, which is also fundamental for horse meat. Although horse meat is considered of particular value, in some countries it is sold at much lower prices than beef, resulting in favorable conditions for fraud to the detriment of European consumers. The same can be said for horse milk as well; often the conditions of the farms where horse milk is produced vary enormously and the levels of control are by no means comparable to those of farms producing other types of milk. Furthermore, the rules governing the treatment of horse milk are unclear and there are no common standards in the Union for inspections and supervision. We must not forget the horse meat scandal and other cases of food fraud that we have already recorded. To improve transparency and safety at all stages of the food chain, it is essential to require that the indication ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, given that the European Union is the largest market for the equestrian industry in the world and that equidae are the most transported animals in Europe in proportion to their population, it is necessary for the Union to lay down rules for the protect them. After all, the World Organization for Animal Health has already issued guidelines on equidae in May 2016. It is therefore necessary to set up reference centers for animal welfare with a view to improving compliance rates and consistent enforcement. disseminating information and best practices on animal welfare, in particular equidae. In addition, equine owners should have a minimum level of knowledge about equine animal husbandry, while ownership implies personal responsibility for the level of health and well-being of the animals they care for.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and in particular its chairman, Mr Siekierski, and the rapporteur, Mrs Girling, for the report on responsible ownership and care of equidae. This report provides an overview of the role of equidae, mainly horses, in today’s society and the importance of the equid sector in the EU economy. The Commission agrees with the authors of the report that the risk to equine welfare needs to be effectively and specifically addressed by Member States, relevant organisations and, of course, keepers of horses and other equidae. The existing animal welfare legislation concerning the keeping, transport and slaughter of animals provides a solid base for Member States to protect the welfare of horses. The Commission for its part will continue to audit the systems in place in Member States to protect the welfare of animals and will act on its findings as and when necessary. As the honourable Members will know, last year saw the adoption of the Animal Health Law, a milestone in the development of EU animal health legislation, which provides for the responsible ownership of animals and requires keepers of animals to have a minimum knowledge of animal health and welfare. With the adoption of the regulation on animal breeding, specific measures have also been introduced, including for the preservation of the genetic diversity in livestock and equidae. I must also mention the proposal for a regulation on official controls, which we hope to conclude during this week’s plenary. The implementation of this new regulation will provide an opportunity to review the rules on traces and the collection and publication of data on the movements of animals and their products. In addition, a crucial role will be played by the future animal welfare reference centres. The discussion on end-of-life horses and imports of horsemeat from non-EU countries was also very important. In this context, I would remind the honourable Members of the ongoing negotiation on the Commission’s proposal on veterinary medicinal products, which is the suitable forum to address the relevant recommendations of the report as regards the administration of veterinary medicinal products to horses. As rightly pointed out in the report, guidance and education are variable supplements to legislation. In this regard, the Commission actively promotes the exchange of best practices, in particular in the field of animal welfare, and has engaged in an enhanced stakeholder dialogue on relevant welfare issues. The recommended preparation of guidelines on good practices in the equine sector can be considered after the legal framework has been established. However, given the wealth of available advice for keepers of horses and other equidae in almost all Member States, I would say that the EU added value of having such guidelines is not so apparent. Let me be clear: the rising number of cases of compromised equine welfare is primarily caused by economics-related choices rather than a lack of accessible information. As regards the international dimension of the report, the Commission would refer to various international agreements to which the EU and the Member States are party, such as the WTO Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures. Meeting our international obligations should not prevent us from adopting higher standards where necessary to protect animal and public health and animal welfare, but such higher standards should, first and foremost, be applied within Member States. The Commission will continue to actively promote EU and international animal welfare standards in third countries. Overall, I consider the report to be a balanced overview of the current challenges of the equid sector and note that most of the recommendations to the Commission have already been broadly addressed and will be followed up, together with Member States, relevant organisations and the equid sector. This report will no doubt assist the Commission, Member States and relevant organisations to keep a focus on equine health and welfare.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: - President! Ladies and gentlemen, Good news at last in the fight against religious persecution: Czech missionary Petr Jasek was released from a Sudanese prison after a year in captivity. The success of Czech diplomacy and the people who stand up for human rights - congratulations. In Sudan, the Open Doors human rights organization surveyed an extreme degree of persecution of Christians. The country ranks fifth in the world rankings of persecution. Sudan's legal system is based on sharia. Apostates are sentenced to death, temples cannot be built. The threat is causing millions to flee to neighboring countries, making their repression a European issue. Yet this successful action is a serious encouragement to us. You can also fight the paranoid dictatorships, you have to! Europe must act as an economic power! Suffering Christians belong to the history of their homeland all over the world. name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as I have had the opportunity to say before you and as I will have the opportunity to say, I believe that effective and pragmatic education is one of the key solutions to the problems facing the European Union. In my opinion, the European Union, in partnership with the Member States, needs to do much more to support quality education for young Europeans. Only education, dear colleagues, can give young people in Europe opportunities and opportunities for a better life. Investing in education, especially in the digital age, which requires employees to acquire new knowledge, is the European Union's chance to become more inclusive, fairer, more open, but also more effective for its young citizens. At the same time, it is education that will give Europe the competitive advantage it so desperately needs today. That is why I believe that, first of all, European programs and funds that focus on vocational training and education must be a priority for all of us. They need to be supplemented and used effectively, and in turn Member States have a duty to support education much more than they currently do.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!We all observe with concern the political events in Turkey: human rights violations, limitation of political rights.Turkey is said to be turning from a liberal democracy into an open dictatorship.In the Netherlands, on the other hand, is - as we are told - liberal democracy.However, can a liberal democracy break international law by not allowing a minister to enter his country's consulate?Does a liberal democracy use clubs, water cannons and dogs against peaceful demonstrators?Do Dutch people of Turkish origin have fewer rights than native Dutch people?So far, I have associated liberalism and democracy with something else, perhaps because I am Polish.So I call on President Timmermans to urgently start checking whether there has been a breach of European values in the Netherlands and whether there is a growing racism threatening the rule of law there.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the day before yesterday I was in Aleppo with some colleagues to learn more about the humanitarian situation on the ground. Let me share some thoughts with you.  First, the humanitarian situation in Aleppo is awful. About two million people, one-third of them children, have no access to clean water or medical services and they are facing environmental disaster. They are breathing high levels of concrete and rock dust. Many of them badly need psychological treatment. Second, according to officials, religious leaders and ordinary civilians, the level of awareness of EU aid in the regime-controlled areas is zero. Third, religious leaders of all denominations whom we met in Aleppo have confirmed that they are ready to be intermediaries in the distribution of EU humanitarian aid. We can trust them even if we do not trust Assad. Colleagues, the civil war has caused a lot of misery. Europe should help civilians living in the territories under the regime’s control. We should reopen the debate on the policy of sanctions, considering the difficult humanitarian situation in Syria. This is unavoidable if we really want to participate in the process of reconciliation.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, the ongoing negotiations between the Greek Government and the creditors on the second evaluation of the Greek program demonstrate the inability of the European institutions to guarantee the fundamental human rights on which the Union is supposed to rely in accordance with Article 2. of its founding Treaty and in accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. European institutions observe almost silently the International Monetary Fund demanding the continuation of the demolition of collective bargaining, the further weakening of the right to strike and the full "liberalization" of redundancies. However, the deregulation of the labor market and the further reductions in tax-free and pensions are not real reforms, nor will the otherwise existing weaknesses of the Greek economy be corrected in this way. Greece needs serious development planning and courageous debt relief in order to stand on its own two feet.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, recently, Janusz Korwin-Mikke MEP filled this Chamber with hate with discriminatory, racist, misogynistic and cowardly speech, because the voice of hate is the voice of fear.Today, on the same stage, I want to convey the courageous voice of a million European citizens who have signed - which we have signed -, through the civic platform Avaaz, a petition so that this action does not go unpunished.Today we have the obligation to demonstrate to European citizens that our institutions defend the values of tolerance, integration and equality on which the European Union is based.That is why we are calling for a strong sanction, as well as exploring legal avenues to prevent this Parliament from being a loudspeaker of hatred and discrimination.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I take the floor to report an emergency: a very serious environmental contamination is underway to the detriment of the citizens of Alessandria and its province. The Piedmontese environmental agency has found concentrations of 305,000 asbestos fibers per liter in the groundwater near the city. That water reaches our citizens and could be used for cooking or for personal hygiene, thus transferring the very dangerous fibers from the water to the air. Breathing even a single fiber can be deadly and, in the same way, harm by ingestion is not excluded, as some recent studies show. Where does asbestos found in groundwater come from? Surely from the excavated earth contaminated by asbestos, coming from the great work known as the "Terzo Valico", crammed into the quarries on the outskirts of Alessandria. That is why we will submit another written question to the European Commission and we will support our colleagues and Alexandrian citizens in their efforts to obtain truth and justice. Someone is trying to transform Alessandra into the new land of fires: but we will not allow it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: - Mr President, after Brexit, the European Union will also face new financial challenges, as it is estimated that European budget revenues can fall to as much as 15%. I therefore think it is high time we realized, firstly, the issue of our own resources. Secondly, they have improved the payment discipline of the Member States and, thirdly, they have also analyzed the European budget, where there is room to reduce consumption expenditure, but certainly not to reduce investment for the future. I also believe that we should maintain cohesion policy, because cohesion means cohesion, and we need it most now. I think we should focus on areas where we can achieve the best possible results for our citizens, and that is digitization, energy or capital union. Nor should we resign ourselves to the issue of the enlargement of the Union, because every enlargement has been successful so far and has meant strengthening economically, culturally, politically, and I believe that ...

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the current global context, when the leaders of the great powers change their economic and security strategies, the European Union must remain united. I am pro-European, and my country is among the top three pro-European countries among the Member States, but I want a fair Europe, with equal treatment of the Member States and the citizens. In the last ten years, the European Union has seen a visible failure in the most important chapter: social cohesion. The white paper presented by Mr Juncker shows a Europe without a clear vision, with Mr Juncker showing an impermissible indifference to a President of the European Commission. The failures of solidarity, security and social cohesion projects are also due to national administrations, but also to European ones. Eastern countries have been stigmatized and even accused of corruption and evasion, although corruption and evasion exist in the countries of Mr Juncker, Mrs Merkel and Mr Hollande. Unhealthy principles applied to spending budgets ("first come, first served") have widened regional disparities. This is a crucial moment and I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to find ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! The inspection, a study conducted by the Supreme Audit Office in Poland showed that the dietary supplement market is assessed as an area of ​​high health risk, because in supplements - mostly of foreign origin - substances that threaten health and life, including narcotic substances and fecal bacteria, were found, and all based on the liberal law of several directives allowing supplements by notification. Therefore, this law needs to be changed. As you can see, the two-speed Europe has existed for a long time, not only because of the poorer quality of products intended for the markets of Central and Eastern Europe. As President Holland said, Europe of the first speed has money and we have rules. The problem, however, is that using money without rules leads to destruction and - as in the case of supplements - to health and life. Such an action, clearly dividing citizens into better and worse ones, does not give any hope.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I would like to welcome the initiative of the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, who was recently in the Western Balkans.She visited all countries in the Western Balkans.I would like to welcome what Commissioner Hahn is doing and I am glad that the European Council has also discussed the situation in the Western Balkans.But I can't help but get the impression that once again we are doing everything once it is completely clear that the Balkans are facing a kind of explosion.I have been following what is happening in the Balkans for 25 years.I have been in full, so to speak, politics for all 25 years.I followed what the European Union was doing and unfortunately I have to say that the European Union is still not fully aware that the countries of the Western Balkans are all sick because they have a virus, a virus of nationalism that needs to be prevented in time.If he is sick, we should prevent, not treat when it is too late.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we came here this week to Strasbourg in the expectation that the British Government was set to trigger Article 50, and yet again we see that there is a delay, as the lack of leadership, the lack of direction among the British Government, again becomes apparent – and the people who, once again, are left to suffer the results are those very people from countries who voted to remain part of the EU. The places we have seen leadership come from are Scotland, where Nicola Sturgeon has shown Theresa May to be the failure in politics that she is, and the North of Ireland, where 70% of the people, when given the opportunity, voted for parties that supported the Remain campaign in the referendum. We need to ensure that the North of Ireland is secured with special status. We did not allow, in the Irish border region, the British military at its height to force a closure of the Irish border. We will not allow the EU institutions to do so now. We need Europe to stand with the people in the North of Ireland.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, today the Venice Commission publishes an opinion on the reform of the Spanish Constitutional Court made by the Government of the Popular Party. The opinion is very critical, despite pressure from the Spanish Government. The Commission warns that the Constitutional Court is affected by its independence if it passes judgment and has to take charge, at the same time, of enforcing it. The Commission also seriously questions the Constitutional Court for the repetitive practice of imposing coercive fines and disqualifying democratically elected public officials. Today another Spanish court has disqualified the former president of Catalonia and two of his ministers. The report shows that the Constitutional reform was made ad casum to oppose legitimate attempts at independence. If in this house we criticize the lack of rigor and the politicization of justice in certain countries, we must also do so, and I do it severely, when it comes to Spain.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to comment on the issue of arms legislation, which we will be discussing here tomorrow. I would like to welcome the changes that have been made to that proposal, which, for example, have defined a weapon using a certain imitation. I think this is a very incredible example of legal amateurism. On the other hand, I would like to welcome the fact that this definition has been dropped, but there are a number of shortcomings left in the proposal, which we are also trying to point out with fellow Members from different countries across the political spectrum. Above all, I am trying to ensure that those legal holders of weapons who have a permit to possess this and do not commit any criminal activity with them, so that they can continue to hold these weapons, even when it comes, for example, to magazines that have more wounds. . At the same time, I would like to ensure the legal certainty of users of paintball weapons and thus these games, ie. to improve the legal protection of arms holders, that should be our goal.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr President, on February 18, in Barcelona, ​​hundreds of thousands of citizens demonstrated to demand a change, to demand a change, in the border and asylum policy of Europe and the Member States. The solidarity of millions of Europeans collides with the institutional inability to give a just and effective response to the arrival of people seeking refuge fleeing from war and violence. Many live astonished at the inability to put the relocation system into operation, and that countries like Spain, after the commitment to host 16,000 people, have only welcomed a few hundred ... Many of us are ashamed of the deaths in the Mediterranean 5,000 in 2016 alone. For all these reasons, we demand that the Member States comply with their obligations, we demand humane and dignified treatment of refugees and we demand that it be possible to legally reach Europe - humanitarian visas - and that deaths end the Mediterranean.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, Turkey continues its provocations against Greece. At the political level, Erdogan, as the new sultan, declares that Turkey is not bound by the Lausanne Treaty and wants to repeal it. Other Turkish officials question the Greekness of 18 Aegean islands, while Turkish Foreign Minister Tsavousoglou says Imia is allegedly Turkish. At the military level, Turkey violates Greek airspace and Greek territorial waters on a daily basis. In addition, a Turkish warship fired artillery shells into Greek territorial waters in Farmakonisi. For the last month and a half I have been with the people of Lesvos, Chios and Samos and on Saturday I will be in Kalymnos with my compatriots, to send the message to Erdogan and his company that the Greek people are not afraid of threatens him and once again tells him: Take Molon.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, after the elections in Macedonia, President Ivanov does not want to hand over power to the opposition. His reasons are, as he stated, that ‘he does not like the programme of the opposition’. According to the President, the governing agreement that includes the Albanian parties will destroy the country. Well, I am sorry to say, but since these were fair and legitimate elections, whether the President or Prime Minister likes the results or not, whether they like the opposition programme or opposition agreement or not, it does not matter. A very dangerous situation is developing in Macedonia. The ruling party is organising demonstrations trying to arouse nationalistic sentiments. Macedonia is like an overheating oil pan waiting for the match to light it up. The EU needs to say, clearly and loudly, that the election results have to be respected, and the High Representative has to explain that the Macedonian President ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, so the radical House of Lords amendments were voted down today by the Westminster Brexiteers, and the Brexit wreck-it gang tell us to get over it: that it is the best thing since sliced bread! Yet I have not met one business person, one young person, one farmer, one man, woman or child who has said to me, rubbing their hands in glee, ‘God, this divorce from the EU is going to be very good!’ But Ireland is told: ‘Get over it. Do not worry about it. It is going to be a frictionless border’ – whatever the hell that means, nobody knows. And let me put the record straight to everybody here: no border, hard or soft, will be accepted by the people of Ireland. What British armoured cars and tanks and guns could not do in Ireland, 27 Member States will not be able to do. So Theresa, your notion of a border, hard or soft, stick it where the sun does not shine, because you are not putting it in Ireland!

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, two years of disqualification from holding public office and a € 36,500 fine. This is the price that, in the Spanish State, is paid to put the ballot boxes and allow the Catalans to decide our political future. The price has been set today by the Superior Court of Justice of Catalonia with an undemocratic ruling, after an embarrassing political trial. The price will be paid by our former president and two of his former councilors, although, in the end, who will pay it will be democracy, which is weakened by such attacks. If this is a warning to sailors, here is another one. They won't stop us. Neither with sentences, nor with fines nor with other types of threats. Because in Catalonia there are thousands of public officials that we are not going to forget about our commitment to democracy and because there are hundreds of thousands of Catalans at our side who will also defend our right and our democratic dignity. The Spanish State puts a price on the ballot box, but we know that freedom is priceless.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – Mr President, during the last plenary we heard President Juncker’s five scenarios about the future of Europe. What these plans lack is the Commission’s position on enlargement. The 27 leaders of the 27 Member States celebrate the 60th anniversary of the European founding treaties. But what will be the message conveyed from Rome to the candidate states? The Western Balkans’ fragile stability needs strong signals from the European Union that will assure Serbia, Macedonia, Albania, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina of their rightful place in the future of the European Union. Everybody knows that there are some pressing European issues like Brexit, migration, elections in some Member States, but we have to take the expectations of our partners in the Western Balkans more seriously, otherwise we might lose them. Migration is still very much present, and Europe’s overall security simply cannot bear any additional instability in this neighbourhood.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the idea of ​​a two-speed Europe is dangerous for the very existence of the European Union. Two different models of approach, one for the West and one for the others, will give rise not to a unitary Europe from an economic, social and political point of view, but rather to creating two Europeans: one rich and one poor. The situation will be favorable for the rise of the nationalist-revisionist parties, for which the dissolution of the European Union is the main programmatic goal anywhere in Europe. Yes, it is time for the European Union to go through a process of reform, but a reform program in the spirit of European ideas must be based on the strengthening of the Union's democratically elected institutions and an accelerated debureaucratisation of the European Commission's decisions. Perhaps it is time for a real democratization of the Union's management, and it would not be out of the question to develop a new system for electing the members of the European Commission and its President, who should also have the direct vote of Europeans behind them. If instead we give the population a plan to widen the social and economic gap between the Member States ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, submission to the euro and its rules, the colossal dimension of public debts and the monopolistic domination of banking are three factors that constrain economic and social development, limit growth, accentuate the dependence of several countries and the imbalances and the inherent inequalities. It is not possible to continue to ignore the weight and consequences of these three constraints. It is of utmost convenience that, as soon as possible, at European level, a process of renegotiating public debts and a framework for an organized exit from the euro of countries whose permanence in the single currency has proved unsustainable, minimizing the disturbances inherent in the euro. process. The liberation from submission to the euro, with the recovery of monetary sovereignty, the renegotiation of public debts in terms, interest and amounts and public control of the bank, more than scenarios that must be considered, are, today, a need that the reality imposes on the evidence.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - President! The U.S. State Department’s annual human rights report makes serious criticisms of the situation of minorities in Romania. It is important to see this in the light of the fact that it has been confirmed that the statement of the Romanian Head of State, Klaus Johannis, that the protection of national minorities is a model in Romania does not correspond to reality. According to the Washington report, the return of church property has actually stopped, and in some cases even nationalization has taken place. It also notes that the authorities are obstructing the use of minority symbols, including the Szekler flag, that, despite existing laws, there are problems with the use of the mother tongue in the administration and judiciary, but also in healthcare, and complains that an association has not been registered with the court because it contains the word Szeklerland, which does not exist legally, in its name. Numerous other criticisms support this: the problems of the national minorities living in Romania, the 1,200,000-strong Hungarian community, still deserve attention.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, agri-food is constantly growing and often represents a privileged ground for investment by the underworld, with dangerous impacts also on the health of citizens and on the environment. In Italy the agromafia represents a turnover of about 150 billion per year: parallel production channels, apparently legal, pollute the supply chain with mafia methods, from the appropriation of land and livestock to the control of transport, up to the point of imposing brands and products, studying the orientation of tastes and draining national and European public resources and funding. I wanted to draw attention to this issue to remind you, on the eve of the presentation of the fifth report on agri-food crimes in Italy, that all institutions are called upon to raise the threshold of attention on this phenomenon. Legislation must be in step with the times, taking into account rapidly growing phenomena, such as online sales and the current international export system. The mafia is evolving and its increasingly evolved forms must be fought by all means.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Czech television station Prima recently drew attention to the numerous cases of truck drivers who had been wrongfully fined by the British authorities for transporting illegal migrants on their way through Calais. The cases look the same on the hair. Migrants try to enter the UK illegally, enter the cargo hold without the drivers' knowledge, and are then exposed on the British side. Unfortunately, fines are imposed even when drivers have confirmed security checks from French police officers. In addition to drivers, carriers are also financially penalized, which is directly liquidation for many companies. Ultimately, the most affected are honest drivers who lose the desire to work in their field, and some companies are even considering leaving the market. The British police and authorities must unconditionally reconsider their approach, the situation is unsustainable. And we need to discuss how to change it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, more than 7,000 women, mostly Romanians, live in slavery on farms in southern Italy, according to estimates made by Italian police and published in The Observer. In an extensive report among the victims, the serious abuses to which these people are subjected, who are in a desperate situation, were presented. As a Romanian who has lived abroad for many years, I cannot accept this situation and see that only one farmer has been convicted so far for abuse, and the only solution found by the authorities was to open a motel for people fleeing by violent employers. I wonder why there is no reaction from the European authorities, especially since these situations have been presented to the European Parliament before. Is this a multi-speed Europe, in which certain citizens are considered second-class citizens, in which their exploitation becomes normal, in which no one speaks and in which there are no solutions to ensure a decent life? We must react now, for Europe to truly become its citizens again, and the first step is for us to react firmly and in solidarity to anywhere in Europe where an illegality, abuse or injustice is committed.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, if the European Union continues as it has so far, voter frustration at the discrepancy between their expectations and the EU's real potential will increase.However, it is not only the Member States and their governments who are to blame for the success of European policies, but also all the responsibility for the difficulties and the joint decisions taken with Brussels.Those who do not respect the principle of subsidiarity and the division of competences, as well as the will of the citizens of the Member States, also bear their share of the blame.Formal implementation of a multi-speed Europe could perhaps solve these problems.However, it is important that both parameters of enhanced cooperation are maintained.Voluntary participation and the obligation to accept any cooperating state.Otherwise, there is a risk that the new Member States will once again become a buffer between the West and Russia.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – I am looking at the image of a destroyed home in Nusaybin in Turkish Kurdistan. This house belongs to the mother of a Kurdish university student now resident in my Manchester constituency. The house was recently destroyed for the second time by the Turkish State, along with the homes of seven other relatives all destroyed first in 1989 and again in 2017. Many people have lost their lives as well as their homes, killed by the Turkish military. The Kurdish issue has not been settled in Turkey and never will be whilst Erdogan’s fascist dictatorship continues to wage war against its own people, arresting and jailing thousands of educators, artists, trade unionists, journalists, civil society activists, public officials and democratically elected HDP politicians. Last month, I joined an EU-Turkey Civic Commission international delegation, with amongst other things, the purpose of visiting Abdullah Öcalan, the Kurdish leader imprisoned in appalling conditions on İmralı island since 1999 … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on 15 June we will see the abolition of roaming charges across Europe, and it has come to my attention that some mobile operators in Ireland are altering the terms of customer contracts before the abolition of charges due to kick in in June. I have spoken to a number of consumers whose mobile providers have informed them that they are planning to change their terms and conditions in order to offer unlimited data to home users while charging an additional price for, and capping, data when users are roaming in the EU. I believe that this is an attempt to circumvent EU law and the roam-like-at-home principle. We need to be tough on these operators. It must be made clear that there is no loophole whereby part of the domestic data allowance could be regarded as a gift or a side benefit and would not count when travelling abroad. The end of the roaming charge, as we all know, was a hugely popular consumer initiative that took many years to complete. It demonstrated to customers and consumers across the EU the very positive side of the European Union and the benefits that it offers them. What is involved here is roaming charges by stealth, pure and simple.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thank you for the honour of being the last to speak in this House today. If the Rome Declaration to be on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of our European Union will be about the vision of a multi-speed Europe, then it will become not less than the death certificate of the European project. I strongly believe the citizens of Europe deserve better. A vision for the future must not formalise the present-day frustrations. Our common vision for the future of the EU has to build on our most cherished asset, which is our unity. We must rebuild mutual trust, giving back hope to all the citizens of Europe. The EU I believe in – the vision to motivate my Hungarian community in Transylvania – is a union of the European nations and national communities: a Europe of its regions, bringing its citizens ever closer to each other.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: This item on the agenda is thus closed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the 2016-2017 session of the European Parliament closed.
